title: Demolition finally begins Mohamed Hadids half built Bel Air mega mansion
story: Share this article Because Hadid - once frequently dubbed a 'multi-millionaire' - claims he's broke and facing $60million in losses over his dilapidated project, half of that his own money and the other half loans.He also claimed that he owes an additional $15million in other court judgements against him, he had to 'drastically downsize' from a 48,000 square foot home to a more 'modest' one, he's made nothing from the caviar and champagne products carrying his name, and his daughters' eyewear line - also using the Hadid brand - has also earned him no money.It was in November 2019 that LA Superior Court Judge Craig Karlan declared Hadid's mansion a 'clear and present danger' to the local community and ordered it to be torn down.Yet the house - which dominated the skyline in its exclusive Bel Air enclave - continued to stand through today because Hadid claimed he doesn't even have the $5million to demolish it.And a buyer who had offered $9million to purchase the building - and tear it down- backed out of the deal. Douglas Wilson, the receiver Judge Karlan appointed to supervise the sale and demolition of the house, was forced to put the property up for auction and it finally sold in December for $5.05million to Sahara Construction, based in Moorpark, west of LA. Wilson - who oversaw the $35million repair of Donald Trump's California golf course when three holes collapsed into the ocean in 1999 - also persuaded Sahara to take on the demolition of the house as part of the deal. Over the past two years, Hadid has tried several legal moves to try to stop or delay the demolition. First he filed chapter 11 bankruptcy, claiming he 'couldn't afford' the $5million demo cost. That was dismissed.Then he filed an appeal against Judge Karlan's order to tear down the giant house. That too was denied.He went to California's Supreme Court to try to save his project. But the state's highest court torpedoed his efforts, refusing even to hear the case.Still undeterred, Hadid's lawyers filed a second appeal - this time against Judge Karlan's decision to appoint a receiver to oversee destruction of the house. He lost that appeal as well.Last month, Hadid's legal team filed a third appeal, this one against the $2.9 million judgment awarded to the neighbors by the civil trial jury.

title: Paramount Plus offered British TV views streaming service launches Summer
story: Share this articleThe company also announced that the third instalment of John Krasinski's A Quiet Place is scheduled for 2025, following the huge success of the sequel in 2021, which was instrumental in encouraging people back to cinemas after long Covid closures.The film is likely to see Krasinski's wife Emily Blunt reprise her role as a mother desperate to protect her family as blind creatures with extremely sensitive hearing run rampage.The US version of the service is already home to Yellowstone spin-off 1883, starring Tim McGraw and Faith Hill, and upcoming series The Offer, about the making of The Godfather, starring Miles Teller, Juno Temple, Matthew Goode and Giovanni Ribisi.Among a raft of announcements of new series is new Star Trek show Strange New Worlds, starring Anson Mount as Captain Pike Rabbit Hole, a psychological thriller starring Kiefer Sutherland and an update to Fatal Attraction starring Lizzy Caplan and Joshua Jackson.The company also announced Grease: Rise Of The Pink Ladies, a musical prequel to the classic film, updated with new music and choreography.It will also premiere a new Beavis and Butt-Head movie, followed by new episodes of the animated series, while South Park will premiere two events on Paramount+ each year for the next six years and all episodes will be exclusive to the service internationally this year and in the US in 2025.The service says it already has more than 50 new international original shows planned as it expands into global markets.The news comes as part of a range of announcements by ViacomCBS following an investor day meeting on Tuesday.ViacomCBS will be rebranded to become Paramount, the company said.Other American streaming platforms like Hulu are not available in the UK, while HBO Max has given its rights to Sky Atlantic.

title: Bristol bar branded Britains right pub refusing serve unethical major brands
story: Share this article Lemmy added: 'A lot of the reasons we've taken s*** before in what we choose to stock and what not to is because of land use, water use, worker's rights - to name just a few.'We don't serve Coca-Cola because they have a history of seriously bad use of water in third world countries, that not a lot of people know about. We have been labelled ''woke'' and all these weaponised words - which have made us feel pretty vulnerable.'When we have taken the stance which we believe is ethical - we do not want to be made some kind of target. This whole thing with Thatchers has veered into politics because of the Colston thing. Part of it is because we publicly supported the Colston Four - one of them actually drinks in our pub - but that's only a part of it.'We actually stopped selling Thatchers during the pandemic, and haven't had it on draft since, only cans. Thatchers did a really good job of bringing decent cider to the masses but that product is not the same product it was back then - it's no fault of theirs.' Earlier this month campaign group Countering Colston called for a boycott of the brand, because company director Martin Thatcher is a member of the Society of the Merchant Venturers.The society has been criticised for its historical links to the slave trade and Edward Colston. Lemmy said: 'Like any product when you're making millions of gallons, the product quality is bound to go down. Then when the Merchant Venturers thing came up, it was the final straw - and it would have been hypocritical of us to continue selling it after supporting the Colston Four.'People prefer the other ciders we sell anyway!'In a Facebook post last week, the pub criticised the Merchant Venturers and confirmed that it would not be buying any more Thatchers cider and 'when it's gone it's gone for good'.Lemmy said: 'We haven't jumped on a band wagon here - it is part of who we all are and who we have always been. We really didn't expect this and don't see it as something that should be shouted about.'The pub's choices has caused a stir on social media.Claire Horare commented on Facebook: 'Embarrassment. Never going in that pub then. This pub is everything that is wrong in the modern day society.'      Victoria Gardner: 'These landlords are pathetic!! What about not serving alcohol altogether as it wrecks thousands of families yet that's never mentioned hypocritical sad people! Hope they don't smoke, have any sugar and make your own clothes.'Ben Kates said: 'Oh how fabulously virtuous and woke of you. The past is the past.'Graeme Patton added: 'For God sake what next this country is becoming slaves to snowflakes.'Colin Ford added: 'Dear God the world is going mad thanks to snowflakes.'Bacardi's smooth image soured by charges of death plots and terror | Television industry | The GuardianWhy People Are Calling for a Tyskie Beer Boycott

title: Long Covid caused virus damaging crucial vagus nerve scientists claim
story: Share this article Damage to the blood vessels caused by the coronavirus has also been heavily linked to long Covid. Official estimates show around 1.3million Britons, 2.1 per cent of the population, have long Covid-like symptoms that last at least four weeks after infection. But because the condition is hard to define and figures are based on self-reported symptoms, it is hard to know exactly how many people are affected by the condition.Fatigue, shortness of breath and loss of smell or taste are the most common ongoing symptoms.To examine the role of the vagus nerve — roughly 3mm in diameter — in long Covid, medics at University Hospital Germans in Badalona recruited 348 sufferers.Two-thirds of the group had symptoms similar to those who had damaged the nerve — which usually occurs through surgery, physical injury or a tumour. These included diarrhoea, an elevated heart rate, dizziness, difficulty swallowing, voice problems and low blood pressure.Further tests of 22 patients also showed that slightly more than a quarter had a thickened or inflamed vagus nerve. Almost all of them, however, suffered symptoms relating to vagus nerve dysfunction, including diarrhoea, an elevated heart rate and dizziness. Dr Gemma Lladós and Dr Lourdes Mateu, medics at hospital and authors of the study, said the results show most long Covid patients with symptoms of vagus nerve damage had changes in the structure or function of their nerve. 'Our findings so far thus point at vagus nerve dysfunction as a central pathophysiological feature of long Covid,' they added.The findings were presented at the European Congress of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases. Dr David Strain, a senior clinical lecturer at the University of Exeter Medical School who was not involved in the study, said it adds to growing evidence that at least some long Covid symptoms are 'mediated through a direct impact on the nervous system'.He said: 'It is entirely possible that people susceptible to nerve damage are at the greatest risk of developing long Covid. 'In this case this observation tells us little more than nerve damage is a result of Covid, this is greater in those with long Covid and the damage is easy to detect in a long, complex nerve.' But Dr Strain noted that not all persistent symptoms post-infection will be linked with this nerve, so more investigation is needed into the triggers of brain fog and muscle aches. He said drugs used to treat vagus nerve damage could be considered for long Covid.

title: England offer Covid jabs 5s Vaccines rolled non urgent basis
story: Share this article Healthy children face a vanishingly low risk of severe illness from the virus, with only six children dying of the virus in England's first year of the pandemic. And two doses of a jab offers as little as 10 per cent protection against catching the antibody-resistant Omicron variant, UK data suggests.Many scientists have questioned the need to vaccinate children when so many have already had Covid.The Office of National Statistics estimates nearly three-quarters of youngsters aged 8 to 11 had Covid antibodies as of January 10. Normally the JCVI's recommendations are accepted by the Department of Health and implemented within a matter of days.But there are reports that No10 stepped in and blocked its publication last week so it could 'review' the advice.It is unclear what exactly caused the hold up, but in the past ministers have expressed frustration at the JCVI's caution over jabbing children.The group initially dragged its heels on recommending jabs to 12 to 15-year-olds in September, citing a lack of safety data and concerns about side-effects. In the end ministers had to circumvent the JCVI, and relied on Professor Chris Whitty and the chief medical officers in the devolved nations to approve the jabs on the basis they would prevent further disruption to schooling. There is a suggestion the Government wanted to announce the roll out to five to 11-year-olds as part of Boris Johnson's plan for England to live with Covid like flu.That strategy is set to be unveiled in Parliament after the recess on February 21 and include radical plans to ditch even the most fundamental Covid rules.Vaccination rates for children are similarly low in the US, where just three in 10 five to 11-year-olds have received one Covid jab and two in 10 are double-jabbed, according to data from the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).Children are given two Pfizer injections — which are a third of the dose given to adults — three weeks apart.Vaccine uptake is highest among white and mixed-race youngsters and lowest among black children. And children from the richest families are nearly three times more likely to be vaccinated (28.2 per cent) compared to those from the poorest areas (10.7 per cent).CDC data shows 17 per cent of children aged five to 11 rushed forward for their first jab in the month after the US approved the vaccine for the age group on November 2.But since then, uptake has slumped, with only eight per cent of opting to get the jab in the following month.The CDC's website states children as young as six months could be eligible for a Covid vaccination 'soon', with the country's Food and Drug Administration due to make a decision by February 21.But the FDA last week warned its announcement on the rollout to babies and toddlers is at least two months away. It is waiting for an update on the efficacy of three doses in the age group from Pfizer before it makes a decision.

title: caution urged over relaxation of covid restrictions in schools
story: The Teachers’ Union of Ireland warned that a sudden relaxation of measures could disrupt preparation for the Junior Cycle and Leaving Cert exams. Photograph: iStockTeaching unions and school managers are urging a cautious and gradual relaxation of Covid-19 rules.The National Public Health Emergency Team (Nphet) is expected to recommend the easing of public health rules relating to the mandatory wearing of face masks and physical distancing in schools when it meets on Thursday.It will also consider giving the green light for the resumption of activities such as school concerts, plays, choirs and in-person parent-teacher meetings.Minister for Education Norma Foley said on Wednesday that public health advice had served schools well during the pandemic and that whatever changes are recommended would be implemented in the education system.She said she anticipated that Nphet advice around hand hygiene and the need for symptomatic staff or pupils to stay at home, as well as enhanced cleaning, would likely remain in place .However, staff representatives say the volume of Covid-19 in schools remains a challenge and is resulting in high levels of pupil and teacher absences.The Irish National Teachers’ Organisation (INTO) called for a “pragmatic and cautious” approach to any changes to Covid-19 mitigation measures in schools.‘Assurances’“We have sought assurances that infection prevention and control measures would remain in place in both primary and special schools for the 28 school days between the mid-term break and the Easter holidays, at the very least,” a spokesman said. “We have also set out our concern at the challenging situation in schools in recent weeks, despite these measures still being in place.”The Teachers’ Union of Ireland (TUI) also urged caution and warned that a sudden relaxation of measures could disrupt preparation for the Junior Cycle and Leaving Cert exams. TUI general secretary Michael Gillespie said thousands of exam-year students are facing into oral, practical and project work deadlines over the coming weeks.“If we stop everything all of a sudden, there is a risk that we’ll have lots of students and teachers missing. We’re urging a cautious approach,” he said.“We’re not calling for masks to be retained, necessarily, but we know that the measures we’ve had in place have managed to keep the number of cases below those in the wider community.”The two main school principals’ representative groups said they will be guided by whatever public health measures are announced.‘Follow the science’Páiric Clerkin of the Irish Primary Principals’ Network (IPPN) said: “Public health advice has guided us in the past and it’s important that we follow the science and do whatever is needed to keep children and staff as safe as possible.”Paul Crone of the National Association of Principals and Deputy Principals added that school leaders will implement whatever changes are recommended.Some inidual principals, meanwhile, said they look forward to a full resumption of school activities.Matt Melvin, principal of St Etchen’s National School in Kinnegad, Co Westmeath, said: “It will be fantastic to get back to sport, drama, art and music. It is so much part of the wider cultural and co-curricular experience . . . whatever happens, I hope that decisions are made on the basis of a public health rationale, rather than any political or social imperative.”Mark Boobbyer, warden of St Columba’s College in Dublin, said: “Personally, I’d be very happy to get rid of the restrictions. We haven’t been able to have whole-school assemblies for two years.“I worry that the restrictions have led to a fracturing of community. We’ve really missed the school concert, the house singing competition and assemblies and full chapel services.”

title: storm dudley and storm eunice power outages reported as new orange alert issued for friday
story: Waves hit the sea wall at Portstewart in Co Derry on Wednesday amid the arrival of Storm Dudley. Photograph: Niall CarsonPA WireA status yellow wind warning associated with Storm Dudley came into place for the entire country from noon on Wednesday, until 11.30pm on Wednesday night. During this period westerly winds were expected to reach average speeds of between 50 and 65kmh, with damaging gusts of between 80 and 110kmh.The winds are expected to be stronger on exposed coasts and on high ground, while a combination of high tide and strong winds will lead to the possibility of flooding on Atlantic coasts. Power outages have already been reported across the country. In an update to the situation on Wednesday afternoon, Met Éireann said Storm Dudley was already making its presence felt, with Donegal County Council warning of dangerous conditions at sea. High winds are already being experienced in most coastal areas with the public advised to stay away from coastal promenades and seashores. Met Éireann hydrometeorologist Jennifer Canavan said Ireland was “in a period of high tides at the moment and this in combination with strong winds and stormy conditions means there is a high risk of large coastal waves and coastal flooding on Friday, especially along southern and eastern coasts.“As such we’re urging people to take extreme care near coastal areas and paths.”A status yellow marine gale warning is in place for all coasts of Ireland and on the Irish Sea until noon on Thursday, with winds expected to reach gale force 8 or strong gale force 9.Storm EuniceMet Éireann said a blustery day will follow on Thursday with a mix of bright spells and some heavy showers, before cloud, rain and strengthening winds arrive ahead of the second storm, Storm Eunice. Met Éireann meteorologist Matthew Martin said the national forecaster expected Storm Eunice to bring further challenging conditions, “especially on Friday morning as strong winds, heavy rain and snow moves across the country”. “At the moment it looks like northern and western areas are most likely to see the heaviest snow falls, with southern areas expected to see the strongest winds, however we’re still a few days ahead and the details of when and where are likely to change,” he said. “With this in mind, we’re urging people to keep a very close eye on the forecast and warnings for their area as these may change in the coming days.”The UK Met Office also issued a status orange wind warning for Antrim and Derry from 2pm on Wednesday until midnight, which it said will bring a period of very strong and disruptive winds.A yellow wind warning is in place meanwhile for Antrim, Armagh, Down, Fermanagh, Derry and Tyrone from 1pm on Wednesday until 6am on Thursday.Gerry Murphy, a forecaster with Met Éireann, said earlier on Wednesday that there was a risk of power cuts later in the day as a result of Storm Dudley.Friday warningsA yellow snow, wind and rain warning is in place for Ireland from 1am on Friday until 3pm that day, with “very strong winds and falls of heavy rain, sleet and snow” expected during this time, Met Éireann said.“Some disruption is likely along with a possibility of coastal and spot flooding,” it added.A status orange wind warning has also been issued for Clare, Cork, Kerry, Limerick, Waterford, Galway, and Wexford from 5am on Friday to 11am that morning. Met Éireann said that as a result of Storm Eunice these areas could see severe and potentially damaging winds during the period of the orange warning, gusting up to 130kmh, higher in exposed areas.Warnings will be further updated on Thursday morning.Storm Eunice should clear by Friday afternoon when it will move to the west coast of England, where it is likely to cause severe disruption.Once Storm Eunice clears, there would still be cold weather with showers of hail, sleet and snow.The weather will remain unsettled overnight on Thursday, as Storm Eunice begins to track eastwards over Ireland through Thursday night and Friday. Met Éireann have said the weather will be “very unsettled for the week”.An orange marine gale and storm force warning is in place for all Irish coastal waters and on the Irish Sea on Friday, with cyclonic winds forecast to reach gale or strong gale force, and reaching storm force 10 or higher at times.That warning is in place from just after midnight on Friday morning until 9pm that night. UtilitiesMeanwhile, Gas Networks Ireland said it does not anticipate any disruption to gas supplies during this week’s forecasted storms.“Ireland’s gas network is one of the safest and most modern gas networks in the world and with the added security of its 14,617km of pipeline being underground it is unlikely to be impacted by adverse weather conditions,” it said.“All works are currently scheduled to take place as normal, however as the safety of our staff, customers and the public is paramount, our teams will assess conditions locally and may defer some work if required for safety reasons.”The utility’s emergency services will continue to operate as normal, regardless of what alert is in place, it added.The Government committee that co-ordinates responses to emergencies met on Tuesday to prepare for the storms. The team held a second virtual meeting on Wednesday with Met Éireann, the OPW, local authorities, response agencies, and key Government departments in preparation for Storm Dudley and Storm Eunice. The team will continue to liaise with Met Éireann to monitor the evolving weather patterns and intends to conduct a further meeting at noon on Thursday.In a statement on Wednesday evening it said that only necessary travel should be undertaken during periods of orange weather warnings.Around the country precautionary measures are being taken in case of flooding. Waterford City and County Council has said flood barriers for the City and Passage may be deployed on Thursday afternoon and the situation is being actively monitored. The Road Safety Authority has appealed to road users to exercise caution over the coming days.Five-day nationwide forecasts, weather warnings and rainfall maps Stay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: bayeux tapestrys 960 year old mistakes uncovered amateur embroiderer
story: A soldier with two left hands. A sailor with no facial features. A courtier with one red leg and one white.Nightmarish as these tableaux might sound, they derive not from a horror film but from the Bayeux Tapestry. Long regarded as one of the most important records of English history, the tapestry turns out to be riddled with errors.And these errors go beyond the famously ambiguous death of King Harold, who might be the soldier struck in the eye by an arrow, but who might also be the inidual slashed by a cavalryman’s sword and trampled underfoot.Mia Hansson, an amateur embroiderer from Wisbech, Cambridgeshire, is six years into her project of making a full-size replica of the tapestry. The original, of course, is 230ft in length and tells the story of the Norman conquest of England, culminating in the Battle of Hastings and – spoiler alert – the victory of William the Conqueror.Thought to date to the 11th century, the tapestry has previously been hailed as “one of the supreme achievements of the Norman Romanesque” by Sylvette Lemagnen, author of the 2005 book La Tapisserie de Bayeux. Its status assured, Lemagnen says, by its “exceptional length, the harmony and freshness of its colours, its exquisite workmanship, and the genius of its guiding spirit.”Perhaps it is time to dock a few marks from this mainstay of British history teaching. Over the six years in which she has been painstakingly copying the tapestry, Ms Hansson has identified at least 15 mistakes in the original.They begin with the sailor, who has a rope running across the void where his face should be. They continue with a mounted soldier whose chainmail is rounded in the portion above his waist and square beneath it – a discrepancy that Ms Hansson ascribes to the tapestry being embroidered by two people at once. The errors continue with the men carrying the coffin of Edward the Confessor – look closely and you will see that there aren’t enough legs to go round.Given that Ms Hansson still has roughly another six years’ worth of work to go, we can safely forecast that more errors will emerge.But she is not amending them, despite her professional instinct – Ms Hansson, 47, is a trained primary school teacher – to correct. She is reproducing the tapestry, she says, “as faithfully as I can, because they did an enormous job. This is a masterpiece, this embroidery, and who am I to come and correct what they’ve done? I’m trying to honour it, warts and all.”That said, the errors can be frustrating. “This is going to turn my hair grey,” she said. “I’m working on a piece now where the back leg of a horse is just simply wrong.“There’s everything wrong about it and I have to copy that and it’s doing my head in.”Ms Hansson has also turned the tapestry into a colouring book. She will display the unfinished replica tapestry at St Peter’s Church Hall in Wisbech on April 12.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine crisis: Moscow creating &#39new normal&#39 to contest sovereignty in Europe, says NatoInvestment visas for dodgy Russian businessmen to be scrapped under Home Office plansTeam York: Who’s still backing Prince Andrew and can they save him?Ursula von der Leyen under pressure to freeze EU cash to Poland and HungaryOrgan transplants one step closer to ‘Holy Grail’ as scientists convert blood types in world firstStorm Eunice: ‘Stay indoors’ alert as 100mph gusts set to cause chaosMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: covid vaccine children five 11 year olds england offered jabs
story: Covid vaccines are to be offered to six million children aged five to 11 from April – but ministers have said the decision is up to parents.The Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation (JCVI) on Wednesday confirmed it had given the green light to the rollout of jabs for young children. It will begin in April, with children offered two jabs 12 weeks apart on a non-urgent basis.Last week The  revealed that the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation (JCVI) had drawn up the advice, which ministers have been considering.On Tuesday, Wales became the first country in the UK to announce that it would be offering a Covid vaccine to all five to 11-year-olds, with Scotland, England and Northern Ireland following suit on Wednesday.The JCVI advice follows months of debate between scientists about whether to back the rollout of jabs for the age group. It said children should be offered vaccines to protect against severe Covid in advance of a potential new wave.Sajid Javid, the Health Secretary, said the rollout would be non-urgent. The programme is planned for the spring and summer, with jabs likely to be administered in school holidays. Ministers were at pains to stress that it is up to parents to decide whether the benefits for five to 11-year-olds are worth vaccination. Around 85 per cent of  children are estimated to have already been infected with Covid.Scientists warned that parents should not wait until any future wave has begun spreading before getting their children vaccinated. But they said the programme should not displace that of other childhood vaccinations, including MMR and HPV to protect against cervical cancer, which have been set back by the pandemic.The NHS has also been told that the continued rollout of jabs and boosters to adults and vulnerable young people is a greater priority. Mr Javid said on Wednesday that the NHS will prepare to extend this non-urgent offer to all children during April so parents can, if they want, take up the offer to increase protection against potential future waves of Covid-19 as we learn to live with this virus.Later, he told reporters: First of all, the vaccine is safe and effective. Second of all, this is a non-urgent offer. It is something that's there as an option for parents, and they should decide for themselves whether it's an offer that they want to take up, and all the information they need would be made available for them.The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency, the UK medical regulator, approved the Pfizer vaccine for use in five to 11-year-olds last year.The paediatric dose is one third of the strength of an adult dose after research showed that the immune response from a lower dose in those aged five to 11 was just as good as a full dose for 16 to 25-year-olds.Last week, scientists said the UK was past the point at which vaccinating young and healthy children against the virus would make much difference.But families planning holidays have complained that the lack of jabs for under-12s has left them facing logistical headaches. The majority of countries in Europe are now introducing jabs for under-12s, and some holiday resorts have banned those who are unvaccinated.The JCVI has been ided about the matter for months, with arguments over whether the benefits of Covid jabs are sufficient to support their use in young children.The committee said: Although this age group is generally at very low risk of serious illness from the virus, a very small number of children who get infected do develop severe disease.Latest evidence suggests that offering the vaccine ahead of another potential wave will protect this very small number of children from serious illness and hospitalisation, and will also provide some short-term protection against mild infection across the age group.Prof Wei Shen Lim, the JCVI chairman of Covid-19 immunisation, said: The committee has carefully considered the potential direct health impacts of vaccination and potential indirect educational impacts.The main purpose of offering vaccination to five to 11-year-olds is to increase their protection against severe illness in advance of a potential future wave of Covid.JCVI member Prof Adam Finn, professor of paediatrics at the University of Bristol, said: The risks posed by Covid in this age group are low – but they exist, and parents may wish to reduce them by having their children immunised.Common side-effects such as fever, headaches and malaise do occur in some children following this vaccine but do not last more than a day or two in most cases. Nevertheless, they may result in some school absence.More serious side effects are reported in this age group but are extremely rare and are minimised by using a lower vaccine dose than in adults and a wide 12-week interval between the two doses.Geoff Barton, the general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, welcomed the advice but said headteachers would have liked to have seen a little more urgency, given the extent of the current disruption to the education of children in this age range More from NewsRussia-Ukraine crisis: Moscow creating &#39new normal&#39 to contest sovereignty in Europe, says NatoInvestment visas for dodgy Russian businessmen to be scrapped under Home Office plansTeam York: Who’s still backing Prince Andrew and can they save him?Ursula von der Leyen under pressure to freeze EU cash to Poland and HungaryOrgan transplants one step closer to ‘Holy Grail’ as scientists convert blood types in world firstStorm Eunice: ‘Stay indoors’ alert as 100mph gusts set to cause chaosMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: hms queen elizabeth inside aircraft carrier royal navy flagship
story: The yellow-helmeted flight deck officer leans into a 40-knot wind and raises a small green flag in his right hand. I crouch behind him, clutching my robust but battered high-def camera. A few feet away, a snarling F-35B Lightning Stealth Fighter, sleek as a shark and every bit as lethal, prepares to launch into the steel-grey skies of the eastern Mediterranean.On the bridge, the navigators steer directly into the wind. ‘Steady on designated flying course, one-one-zero,’ says the officer of the watch.  ‘Steady on one-one-zero, sir,’ confirms the helmsman.The F-35B needs plenty of headwind to get airborne. The aircraft has a run-up of only 350 feet to the curved ‘ski-jump’, from which it will make its final leap skywards. Inside the glass-encased flight control tower behind us, the vessel’s Commander Air, Ed Phillips, aka ‘Wings’, looks up and down the massive flight deck and, when satisfied all is clear, gives a short sharp order:All eyes turn to the green flag held aloft and rippling in the wind. Probably worth no more than a couple of quid, it is brought down to the ground with a dramatic flourish the signal for the F-35B, worth well over £100 million, to get airborne.I brace myself for the immense power about to be unleashed. I’ve witnessed this many times and know what to expect. It’ll be exhilarating, for sure, but also terrifying and probably painful. I’m determined to capture on film a spectacular close-up of a launch as near to the aircraft as possible, but the timing is critical and so far I’ve manifestly failed to pull it off.The searing blast from the rear jet nozzle has always blown me off my feet and sent me sprawling. I have the bruises and cuts to show for it and God knows how much skin I’ve now invested in the roughened, diamond-hard surface of the flight deck. But I still don’t have the footage I want. This time, two hefty sailors are ready to hold me down, or at least try to. My fear is that no amount of muscle power will be a match for the explosive thrust of what is essentially a horizontal rocket.The pilot releases the brakes and opens the throttle. The Pratt &amp Whitney afterburning, turbofan engine raises its pitch to a terrifying scream as the aircraft surges forward. I clench my teeth, tense my muscles and, with my heart pounding in my ears, bear hug the camera in a semi-stable position. But how long can I hold on? Four vice-like hands press down on my hunched shoulders.It’s June 2021 and I’ve joined the ship’s company of HMS Queen Elizabeth for her first operational deployment. We are some weeks into a seven-month voyage to the South China Sea, not on exercise but, locked, loaded and ready for action, should it become necessary.The new carrier and fleet flagship, together with eight escorts (destroyers, frigates, supply ships and a submarine) comprise Carrier Strike Group 21 (CSG21) – the most powerful naval force to leave the UK in a generation. Prior to our transit through the Suez Canal and the Red Sea, on our way to the Pacific and the disputed waters of the South China Sea, the ship has been launching waves of jets on Operation Shader – in support of land forces in the fight against Islamic State in Syria. But this has prompted a reaction from the Russians. They consider this part of the Med their own backyard and are intent on letting the QE and her escorts know they’re not welcome here. But the QE is the new dog on the block and she’s here to mark her own territory, not with a wag of the tail but a snarl.Today’s launch of the F-35s, therefore, is not to attack IS but to ward off Russian warplanes attempting to overfly us. Pilots, drawn from the Fleet Air Arm, RAF and US Marine Corps, have been scrambling all day, sometimes in rapid two-minute intervals, to intercept ‘red bandits’ and escort them away at a safe range.The Russians, apart from wanting to goad the Royal Navy, are desperate to get a closer look at the QE, the most advanced aircraft carrier in the world, and also test the Task Group’s reaction procedures – not only in the air but also on the surface, with their warships, and underwater with their submarines. The QE’s Anti-Submarine Warfare Merlin Mk2 helicopters from 820 Naval Air Squadron are on constant patrol in order to monitor subsurface incursions and react accordingly. Nobody has actually opened fire, but there’s a lot of posturing and tactical lip-curling. If this is the start of a new Cold War, nobody is in doubt that things could heat up very quickly. The QE’s magazines are bursting with bombs, bullets and missiles of all descriptions and capabilities, as you’d expect on a warship that is now Britain’s main conventional strategic deterrent.Commodore Steve Moorhouse, leading CSG21, knows that Britain’s potential adversaries, the Russians and Chinese, will prod and poke his Task Group at every opportunity. ‘They want to see what we’re made of,’ he freely admits. ‘And I’m happy to show them, but professionally, in a spirit of confidence, not confrontation.’ Moorhouse is a steely commander but also a diplomat by default. After all, HMS Queen Elizabeth, a chunk of British sovereign territory, is part warship, part floating embassy. As the embodiment of ‘Global Britain’, her charge is to deliver ‘power projection’ on behalf of the nation: on the one hand that means hard-edged, lethal warfare on the other it’s about soft, political persuasion through deterrence, as well as overt support for allies around the world.Friends and foes alike will be watching this deployment with keen interest and I’m here to capture it on film for a forthcoming BBC TV series. But this isn’t the first time I’ve filmed HMS Queen Elizabeth. That was back in 2009, when I witnessed Princess Anne cutting the ship’s first steel at Govan shipyard in Glasgow. This was not so much the birth of Britain’s biggest-ever warship – more like her conception – and I was struck by the enormity of the occasion.  Sir Jonathon Band, the First Sea Lord at the time, spoke with passion to the audience and assembled media. The Queen Elizabeth Class of aircraft carrier, comprising HMS Queen Elizabeth, with HMS Prince of Wales to follow, would, he explained, ‘provide Britain with the means to deliver air power from the sea, wherever and whenever required, and in a stronger and more decisive form than ever before’. They will also, he added, ‘be the centrepiece of Britain’s military capability for many years to come’.The construction of HMS Queen Elizabeth and her sister ship meant a complete reinvention of the Royal Navy but, despite Sir Jonathon’s upbeat messaging, it was to prove a painful and long-drawn-out process. Our active carriers at the time, Ark Royal, Illustrious and Invincible, were about to be axed in the 2010 Strategic Defence and Security Review and with them the Navy’s Harrier squadron – its entire naval fixed-wing capability. Already, naysayers and vocal critics were provoking a heated debate over the pros and cons of a carrier-centric Navy, and whether there’d be enough escort ships to protect the carriers while at sea or sufficient sailors to man them – each would be three times the size of the Invincible Class carriers.General Sir Peter Wall, former head of the British Army, described the decision to build the new carriers as no more than a ‘vanity project’ that ‘lacked credibility’ and which could be seen to have ‘skewed the UK’s conventional defence effort to a damaging degree’. Max Hastings, ever the provocateur, suggested the new warships represented delusions of grandeur for a Navy in decline. Other denigrators were quick to point out that a large carrier is a big target – especially for the new generation of hypersonic missiles that the Chinese call ‘carrier killers’.Russia inevitably chimed in with some of its own political trash talk: ‘Just make sure you keep your new carrier away from Moscow’s warships or they’ll send it to the bottom of the sea.’Military hardware is an emotive subject, especially in the context of huge capital expenditure that might otherwise be spent on housing, welfare or the NHS, but £6 billion for two vessels (albeit a near doubling of the original budget) is modest compared to the eye-watering price tag of USS Gerald R. Ford, an American super-carrier of similar proportions which cost more than $13 billion (and which, according to the Pentagon, ‘has yet to demonstrate it can effectively defend itself from anti-ship missiles and other threats’).The glossy brochure issued by a conglomerate of shipbuilders known as the Aircraft Carrier Alliance certainly suggested that Britain was getting its money’s worth. At 65,000 tonnes, HMS Queen Elizabeth and HMS Prince of Wales would not only be the biggest warships ever built for the Royal Navy, but also the most powerful and advanced in terms of military technology and stealth capabilities – especially when married eventually to the state-of-the-art F-35B Lightning jet fighter.The sales pitch for the super-carriers came with a staggering array of facts and figures. The ships, it claimed, would be so highly automated they’d require only ‘lean-manned’ crews – less than 1,000 per ship, without aircrew. That’s broadly one fifth the size of an American crew on a similar-sized ship. They’d each have a four-acre flight deck, the size of three and a half football fields, nine decks and a hangar big enough to fit two Type 23 frigates side by side. Each carrier would have two propellers weighing 33 tonnes – exerting the same thrust as 50 high-speed trains and producing a maximum speed in excess of 27 knots (31mph). The six engines (two mighty gas turbines and four diesels) would produce enough energy to power a city the size of Swindon the electrical cabling and wiring would stretch six times round the world the ship, weighing the same as 35,000 family cars, would carry enough fuel to take those cars to the moon and back a dozen times… and on it went.The statistics were mind-boggling, but one thing was for sure: the challenge of building the first of these ships – the nine-decked HMS Queen Elizabeth – manning her, taking her to sea and getting her battle-ready was going to be a compelling story, as I learnt while following her construction in seven shipyards around the UK, culminating in her final assembly at Rosyth in Fife, like some gargantuan Lego toy. But, engineering aside, I knew that her real story would reside in the sailors yet to arrive the men and women who would breathe life into the country’s first super-carrier.  Foremost among them was Jerry Kyd, the ship’s first seagoing captain. I encountered him on the day he arrived in Rosyth in May 2016, as he addressed a fledgling ship’s company of just 456 sailors standing in front of their ship, still an inert hulk without propellers and dead in the water.‘The world’s a frisky place at the moment,’ he said. ‘And we have to be ready to respond to threats which I think are coming sooner rather than later.’ Kyd glanced towards their future home, encased in scaffolding. ‘HMS Queen Elizabeth, as big and sophisticated as she might be, is really just a huge metal box, full of pipes, wires, gadgetry and computer terminals. She’s missing one vital ingredient…’ He paused dramatically. ‘Without the flesh, blood, muscle and hearts of you, my sailors, that ship is just a robot. You, not the ship, are the most important resource at my disposal.’It was nearly a year before the QE was ready for her first sea trials. As a ‘new build’, there were bound to be problems. On the eve of our departure for the North Sea, Captain Kyd warned that there would be emergencies: ‘We’ll have floods, we’ll have fires. And casualties too. That’s the nature of this business.’For the best part of two months the ship was put through her paces off the coast of Scotland, where I joined them. The first aircraft, a Merlin helicopter, was landed on the flight deck within four days as the ship’s company got used to their largely subterranean existence deep in the belly of the beast. I watched with amazement as the sailors, many of them straight out of training, transformed the massive grey hulk not only into a working warship but a home from home. The QE was fast becoming a vibrant floating city and, with 23 nations represented from across the Commonwealth, all human life was here. My first challenge, however, was to learn my way round a ship longer than the Houses of Parliament and taller than Nelson’s Column and so gigantic that it boasted five kilometres of passageways and 3,200 compartments.Apart from a serious issue with a cracked thrust block that held one of the drive shafts in place, all went as well as could be expected. As Jerry Kyd foretold, there were plenty of fires and floods as the ship was pushed to breaking point so that her technical and seagoing limits could be identified. There were ‘casualties’ too, but thankfully only minor ones – the worst being cracked teeth and broken fingers. Sea trials completed, we finally entered Portsmouth dockyard, the ship’s designated home port, and within months the QE was officially commissioned by the Queen.After a period of maintenance, the ship set off for the next vital stage of her trials off the eastern seaboard of the US. Within hours of leaving Portsmouth we became aware of an ominous presence – a Russian Federation frigate called Admiral Makarov had closed to within two miles of our position. A highly capable warship armed with Kalibr long-range cruise missiles, the Makarov was in transit from the Baltic to Sevastopol on the Black Sea. While officially permitted to route through the English Channel she had clearly erted her course to have a closer look at our ship.  A few days later, just before starting our transatlantic crossing, we were suddenly erted into the Irish Sea to help chase off a Russian submarine spotted in British territorial waters. There was an increasing concern, as there still is, that Russians could be sussing out British underwater power and communication cabling – an obvious target for a potential enemy.  The Russian sub made a run for it as soon as we got close. Even before the QE had become operational the writing was on the wall and it was written very clearly in Cyrillic script. A sign of things to come (and indeed I write this as the world tries to second-guess Russian designs on Ukraine).Following this brief ersion we progressed across the Atlantic and the next dramatic event I witnessed was the ship’s first-ever run ashore in a foreign port, which didn’t go entirely to plan. In Mayport, Florida, after a night of heavy drinking, four sailors from the QE and two from our escort frigate, HMS Monmouth, were arrested for a range of alcohol-related offences including jaywalking, fighting and resisting arrest. Despite making headlines on both sides of the Atlantic, the episode was soon forgotten and at least part of the blame was attached to overzealous policing.  Captain Kyd, a pragmatist, reckoned that a night in jail was punishment enough for sailors letting off steam. ‘The question we have to ask ourselves,’ Kyd told his commanders, ‘is what sort of sailor would we want to go to war with? The automaton who obeys every rule, plays it safe and never takes chances? Or the free spirit who pushes his luck and breaks the odd rule?’    Kyd quickly refocused on the job in hand – namely to see an F-35B Lightning jet land on the ship’s flight deck for the first time. Helicopters were one thing, but a fighter jet that lands vertically using immense downward thrust from its enormous engine was quite another. Commander Nathan Gray, the Navy’s top test pilot, was the first to attempt a landing. It went without a hitch, although many questions remained about safety margins before the flight deck and aircraft could be handed over to front-line combat pilots. Two months of continuous, painstaking testing in all weathers, including a full-blown hurricane, gradually provided the answers. Gray, despite a few near misses, was satisfied that he and his colleagues had done all they could to ready the ship and aircraft for action.  And so to the present. Here I am aboard the QE once again – no longer on sea trials, but busy arm-wrestling the Russians, and before long she’ll be playing cat-and-mouse with the Chinese in the South China Sea. This is the acid test, with much at stake. The Prime Minister has declared he wants the Royal Navy to be the most powerful and influential in Europe by the end of the decade. CSG21 is the first step to achieving that ambition and proving that the new aircraft carrier is no white elephant but an effective instrument of government as well as an iconic symbol of nation.  Great adventure beckons and, once again, all life is here – a much expanded ship’s company of 1,650 men and women. Yes, there are the aviators yes, there are the seafarers yes, there are the marine engineers. But there are so many others: stewards, chefs, medics, gunners, aircraft handlers, writers, warfare specialists, physical trainers and intelligence officers. There is even a specialist chocolatier and, maybe because of him, a dedicated dentist and dental hygienist.‘Bleeding frozen chips!’ shouts Ronnie Lambert, an Essex boy, born and bred. ‘They want 10 more boxes in the main galley and they’re all at the back of the frickin’ fridge.’‘Well, get in there and pull ’em out,’ laughs fellow storeman Aaron Mackin. ‘It’s yer bleedin’ job.’‘Well, I’m transferring to aviation! Them boys have it easy up there. All sunshine and sea.’    The F-35B, accelerating from a standing start, rattles my bones. The heavyset sailors push down hard on my prone body as I attempt to point the camera in the right direction. The sailors are now lying on top of me – the jet stream strikes and skittles us. I roll across the deck, trying to protect my camera. Did I capture the moment of take off? I will check as soon as I can. Lying on my back I look up to see five British F-35s close in on three Russian MiGs.There will be more Russian warplanes soon. They’ll keep coming, but at least we know one thing: we have chips to go with our fish tonight. Must be a Friday.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine crisis: Moscow creating &#39new normal&#39 to contest sovereignty in Europe, says NatoInvestment visas for dodgy Russian businessmen to be scrapped under Home Office plansTeam York: Who’s still backing Prince Andrew and can they save him?Ursula von der Leyen under pressure to freeze EU cash to Poland and HungaryOrgan transplants one step closer to ‘Holy Grail’ as scientists convert blood types in world firstStorm Eunice: ‘Stay indoors’ alert as 100mph gusts set to cause chaosMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: met launches cash for honours investigation prince charless
story: Prince Charles has said he is willing to speak to detectives after Scotland Yard announced it had launched a criminal investigation into an alleged cash for honours scandal involving one of his closest confidants.The politan Police is examining claims that Michael Fawcett, his former right-hand man, had worked with fixers to secure a CBE for the Saudi billionaire Mahfouz Marei Mubarak bin Mahfouz, who had given more than £1.5 million to the Prince’s Foundation charity.The Prince of Wales, who presented Mr Mahfouz with the honorary title at a private ceremony at Buckingham Palace in 2016, has denied any knowledge of the alleged deal.Royal sources have said Prince Charles is willing to speak to police in order to help with the investigation.“There has been no request for help from the police so far, but if he is asked to help he will of course do so,” the source said. A Clarence House spokesman said: “The Prince of Wales had no knowledge of the alleged offer of honours or British citizenship on the basis of donation to his charities.”Scotland Yard confirmed it had launched a criminal investigation into the allegations, which first appeared in the media last year.The Prince's Foundation is an educational charity established in 1986 which brings together a number of projects and causes that Prince Charles is passionate about.The allegations centered around claims that Mr Mahfouz, who denies any wrongdoing, donated large sums to restoration projects of particular interest to Prince Charles.Mr Fawcett - who has been a close aide to the Prince for more than 40-years - resigned as the chief executive of the Prince’s Foundation charity in the wake of the allegations.Detectives liaised with the officials from the Prince’s Foundation after Norman Baker, the former Liberal Democrat MP, made a formal complaint to Scotland Yard.In December, the Prince’s Foundation published the findings of its own investigation into the allegations, which stated there was some evidence of communication between the CEO and fixers regarding honorary nominations for a donor between 2014-18.But the report stated it had found no evidence that the charity’s trustees were aware of this.The police investigation is being led by the Met's Special Enquiry Team, the same unit that is in charge of the Partygate investigation.A Scotland Yard spokesman said: The politan Police Service has launched an investigation into allegations of offences under the Honours (Prevention of Abuses) Act 1925.The decision follows an assessment of a September 2021 letter. This related to media reporting alleging offers of help were made to secure honours and citizenship for a Saudi national.The Special Enquiry Team has conducted the assessment process which has included contacting those believed to hold relevant information.Officers liaised with The Prince’s Foundation about the findings of an independent investigation into fundraising practices. The Foundation provided a number of relevant documents.These documents were reviewed alongside existing information. The assessment determined an investigation will commence. There have been no arrests or interviews under caution.A spokesperson for The Prince's Foundation said: It would be inappropriate to comment on an ongoing investigation.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine crisis: Moscow creating &#39new normal&#39 to contest sovereignty in Europe, says NatoInvestment visas for dodgy Russian businessmen to be scrapped under Home Office plansTeam York: Who’s still backing Prince Andrew and can they save him?Ursula von der Leyen under pressure to freeze EU cash to Poland and HungaryOrgan transplants one step closer to ‘Holy Grail’ as scientists convert blood types in world firstStorm Eunice: ‘Stay indoors’ alert as 100mph gusts set to cause chaosMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: moments see immense value nuclear deterrent
story: Shortly after becoming prime minister, Theresa May was challenged (by the SNP, of course) on Trident and whether there were any circumstances in which she would press the nuclear button. She answered: “Yes.” And all hell broke loose. It was one thing for the independent nuclear deterrent to form the backbone of British and Nato defence policy, but quite another thing to actually state publicly that you would use it.May was right. What would be the point in possessing Trident at all if our political leaders stated publicly that it was only there for show, that in the case an enemy launched a first strike at us, we would defend ourselves with a few sturdy brollies and a whole dictionary of harsh language?Deterrence is about persuading the other side that in the event they chose to launch a nuclear attack at us or our allies, they should know that that would be the equivalent of signing their own, and their people’s, death warrant. That sounds harsh now that I’ve typed it, but there we are. Life is tough. And in a world in which nuclear weapons can’t be uninvented, it’s the best and only way of maintaining international peace.All of this sprang to mind when contemplating the current impasse on the border of Ukraine, where Russia may or may not perform an homage to Germany foreign policy in 1938. It’s arguably the most serious military dispute for the West since the Cuban Missile Crisis of 1962, and certainly the worst since the end of the Cold War. However it’s resolved, we should at least be thankful that so far, no one is considering turning this territorial dispute nuclear. But the only reason that is unlikely is because Nato countries ignored the siren voices of the Left over decades and steadfastly held onto, and upgraded, their nuclear arsenals.Can anyone be in any doubt that, had CND and their fellow travellers successfully persuaded Britain’s leaders to ditch Polaris, Cruise and Trident, the world would be there for the taking by the likes of Putin? I used to ask former constituents who imagined the world would be a safer place without nuclear weapons how such a utopia could emerge. After all, the only countries where peace movements are allowed to press their case are modern liberal democracies how safe would the planet be if America and her allies rid themselves of nuclear weapons, leaving Russia, China and North Korea still in possession of theirs?Yet this is a scenario that is, if not actually embraced by modern day “peace” campaigners, then ignored altogether. Buy the world a Coke and we won’t have to think about all this uncomfortable business about facts and reality.The reason Jeremy Corbyn never made a serious attempt to change Labour’s pro-Trident defence policy while he was party leader was because he didn’t need to. Once prime minister, he could virtue signal his intention never to use them in any circumstance, making them obsolete in a single, publicly broadcast sentence.There were many who, as communism crumbled, subscribed to Francis Fukuyama’s optimistic view of the End of History and his predictions that the global triumph of economic liberalism would ultimately make nuclear weapons redundant. Alas, we remain a long way from that destination. Those who blithely claim that “the world has never been more dangerous” are, I think, wrong. There were points during the Cold War when the world really was on the brink of nuclear Armageddon, and no realistic scenario today can compete with those blood-curdling moments in the 60s, 70s and 80s when the world held its breath.But Putin’s nationalistic designs on neighbouring countries, China’s similar claims on Taiwan and North Korea’s unhinged and borderline psychopathic leadership show that we are a very long way from the point at which the ploughshare industry can expect a boost.The same old naivety that once drove thousands of CND supporters through the streets of London is well replicated in the Twitter accounts of corporate organisations hoping to increase their profit margins by signalling their woke credentials to their younger audiences. “You cannot simultaneously prevent and prepare for war,” was the considered geopolitical and philosophical conclusion reached recently by the makers of Chocolate Fudge Brownie ice cream. Not only can you do both, but in this nuclear age there is no alternative to doing both. The absence of war – or at least the absence of nuclear war – since Hiroshima and Nagasaki is an inescapable and inconvenient fact. Peace has been established through a fear of retaliation, a fear of obliteration.This being earth, there are no comfortable assurances to reach about the military and political strategy of Mutually Assured Destruction (MAD): it may work indefinitely or it may not. But how can anyone doubt that the best way to bring about the apocalypse none of us wants to see is to give up our weapons and leave it to the dictatorships of the world to use them as and when they see fit?More from NewsRussia-Ukraine crisis: Moscow creating &#39new normal&#39 to contest sovereignty in Europe, says NatoInvestment visas for dodgy Russian businessmen to be scrapped under Home Office plansTeam York: Who’s still backing Prince Andrew and can they save him?Ursula von der Leyen under pressure to freeze EU cash to Poland and HungaryOrgan transplants one step closer to ‘Holy Grail’ as scientists convert blood types in world firstStorm Eunice: ‘Stay indoors’ alert as 100mph gusts set to cause chaosMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: organ transplants one step closer holy grail scientists convert
story: All organs may one day be suitable for all patients without the need to first find a blood type match, after a landmark discovery.More than 4,000 people in the UK are waiting for an organ transplant on the NHS, with the majority in need of kidneys which can come from living donors.However, around 1,000 patients need whole organs, such as hearts, lungs or pancreases, that must come from deceased patients.In these cases, doctors must find a suitable match where the donor and recipient are the same blood type because, otherwise, a clash will see the recipient’s immune system recognise the new organ as foreign and attack it.The only exception to this rule is if the donor is type O, as the organs of these people express no identifying features, stripped of any telltale protruding proteins.People who belong to blood group O are therefore known as “universal donors” and their organs can be given to anyone, irrespective of their blood group.And researchers from Canada have now managed, for the first time, to convert an organ from one blood group to another, turning a human lung from type A to O.This was achieved by keeping the pair of lungs healthy and functional in a specialist piece of equipment and then treating one of them with a cocktail of enzymes to strip away the type A identifiers, known as antigens. The other lung was left unchanged.Researchers then tested to see if the process had worked by exposing the lung to blood filled with antibodies that would attack a type A antigen. No rejection was seen, proving that the experiment was a success and they had engineered the world’s first universal organ process.The team treated eight blood type A lungs and discovered the treatment removed more than 97 per cent of blood type A antigens within four hours.One in three people in the UK are A+, and another third are O+. But just three per cent of people are AB. As a result of this natural variation, some people will wait longer for a life-saving transplant as a direct result of their blood group.Although O is common, because it is used as a universal donor, many of these organs end up going to non-O patients, which means that O patients actually end up waiting the longest.This also translates to a higher proportion of waiting list deaths in some groups, the experts say.“With the current matching system, wait times can be considerably longer for patients who need a transplant depending on their blood type,” said Dr Marcelo Cypel, surgical director of the Ajmera Transplant Centre in Toronto, Canada, and the senior author of the study.“Having universal organs means we could eliminate the blood-matching barrier and prioritise patients by medical urgency, saving more lives and wasting fewer organs.”“The treatment described here could … further expand the pool of universal donor organs from the current 55 per cent (blood group O donors) to over 80 per cent,” the researchers add in their study, published in Science Translational Medicine.“As a consequence, this strategy may greatly improve access and fairness of organ allocation.”Robin Vos, chair of the European Cardio Thoracic Transplant Association (ECTTA), told The : “Recent very important achievements in organ bioengineering, regeneration and transplantation highlight the importance of scientific research in the field of transplantation.“Achievement of an immunosuppression-free state has been pursued since the early days of transplant medicine and is considered by many as the Holy Grail for transplant sciences.“The current results, if proven stable, durable and reproducible, may indeed represent another important step towards this goal, universally benefitting all patients in need of an organ transplant.“Disruptive innovations, like the creation of universal blood-type organs, may shape future delivery of trusted transplant care and can truly be considered as landmarks in the history of transplant medicine.”There are various potential ways of resolving the organ shortage, and recent developments in xenotransplantation – using animal organs in people – suggest that this method may also be an option.Genetically-modified pigs provided a heart for a living American man, as well as a kidney that was transplanted into a braindead man, also from America.These successes could see animal organs become a conventional way to treat people with organ failure, but experts say there is no silver bullet and the best way to reduce deaths from organ failure is to encourage more people to become organ donors.NHS Blood and Transplant’s annual activity report shows that there were 26.7 million registered donors in England as of March 2021, up from 26 in March 2020 because of a legislative change to an “opt-out” registry.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine crisis: Moscow creating &#39new normal&#39 to contest sovereignty in Europe, says NatoInvestment visas for
