title: papdale nursery closed due to covid related staff shortage
story: Papdale Nursery has been closed this Friday, due to a shortage of staffing in relation to COVID and other sickness.The temporary closure is expected to continue into next Monday, February .Nursery manager, Caroline Easton, said positive COVID cases and the need for isolation due to others becoming symptomatic had led to the unavoidable decision to close. Parents were notied on Wednesday afternoon.Ms Easton said: “We recognise that this is incredibly frustrating for parents who rely on childcare within the nursery, but we have reached the position where closure is unavoidable given the reduced staffing available.#As I’m sure you will appreciate this is a fast-moving situation, but I will continue to update parents of any changes as timely as is possible.“As always we will work through all contingencies to see how a reopening can be managed safely. We thank you for your patience and understanding during these trying times.”All COVID-related situations within schools and nurseries are reviewed on a daily basis by the inter-disciplinary team which includes representatives of NHS Orkney Public Health, the Council’s Education Service, Environmental Health, Safety and Resilience, and affected schools and nurseries.These authorities say it is vital that everyone continues to carry out twice-weekly lateral flow tests and to report the results, where negative, positive or void online here: https:www.nhsinform.scot campaigns coronavirus-covid--report-your-test-result Self-isolating when you are asked to is the best way to prevent the spread of the virus. It’s very important that you stay at home:More information is available from www.nhsinform.scotcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: partial opening for papdale nursery
story: newsPartial opening for Papdale NurseryFebruary ,  at : pmPapdale Nursery will only be partially open on Wednesday and Thursday - February due to insufficient staffing levels as a result of COVID and other sickness absence.To avoid a full closure, dferent classes will be asked to stay home each day and parents have been notied this afternoon by the nursery manager, Caroline Easton.The long weekend begins on Friday  February – Tuesday  February inclusive when all children and young people will be off.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: covid-jabs-five-11-year-olds---questions-answered
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Primary school childrenHealthy children aged five to  across the UK are to be offered a Covid- vaccine.Here are the answers to some of the key questions about jabs for younger children.– What is the latest The Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationhas advised that healthy children aged five to  should be offered a Covid- vaccine on a “non-urgent” basis.The recommendation has been accepted by ministers across the UK and jabs are expected to be rolled out from April in England.– I thought jabs were approved for use in five to -year-olds in December The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agencyannounced in December that a special “paediatric formulation” of the Pfizer BioNtech Covid- vaccine was safe for use among children aged five to .The JCVI then said that the vaccine could be offered to “at risk” children in this age group, but reserved its decision on wider use among healthy children in this age bracket until now.– Can you tell me more about this “paediatric formulation” Children aged five to  will be offered a much lower dose of the vaccine – lower than that offered to adults or children aged  and over. vw,vw,px, px"They will be offered a  micrograms dose compared with  micrograms.Children will be given two doses,  weeks apart.– Are there any side effects Both data from the clinical trials and real-world experience shows that younger children are less likely to report side effects compared to children aged  and over and young adults.The MHRA has also been monitoring whether there have been side effects among at-risk children who are already receiving the jab.It said the “overwhelming majority” of side effects reported were mild and “self-resolving” such as fever, headache or sore arms.The NHS will make a non-urgent offer of the #COVID vaccine to all children aged - in England during April.This follows new advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation .More info 🔽— Department of Health and Social CareFebruary , A JCVI official said severe adverse reactions were “extremely, extremely rare”.Officials examined lots of data, including information from the US where millions of children aged five to  have been vaccinated. The jab has also been on offer to this age group in a number of countries around the world including Ireland, Canada and Israel.One MHRA official said that parents could be reassured that “this is a very safe vaccine”.– Are children not at low risk from Covid Yes, the vast majority of children are at low risk from Covid-. In fact it is estimated that % of children in this age group have already had Covid, many with mild or no symptoms at all.But a small number are at serious risk of severe illness requiring hospital admission.The JCVI said that offering vaccines to this age group would “protect this very small number of children from serious illness and hospitalisation” in the event of a future wave of disease.– Did the JCVI examine school absences Yes, it was a tricky debate. In the US some % to % of children took time off school after having a jab due to mild side effects but on the other hand, vaccination could prevent some infections and therefore prevent some children needing to take time off school.The JCVI concluded that the effect of vaccination on the disruption to education was “indeterminate”.– I am still on the fence, should I get the vaccine for my child The programme has been called “non-urgent” and officials are keen for parents and carers, as well as children, to be given as much information as possible about the vaccine. vw,vw,px, px"They have acknowledged that it will take some parents time to come to the decision and stressed there would still be an offer of vaccination as children age.– Where will children be given jabs It has not yet been announced where children will be vaccinated but it is now up to the NHS to plan how this will work operationally.At-risk children aged five to  have been able to get vaccinated at their GP surgeries.– How many children will be offered the jab There are an estimated . million five to -year-olds in the UK.Some of these will have already been offered the chance to have a vaccinethey are in vulnerable groups.We want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: storm-dudley-arrives-uk-bringing-80mph-winds-heavy-downpours
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Winter weather Feb th Heavy rain and mph winds have battered parts of the UK as Storm Dudley struck on Wednesday.The Met Office has issued an amber warning for strong winds covering central Scotland, parts of Northern Ireland and northern England above Hull which is expected to last until midnight on Wednesday, with yellow wind warnings in place as far south as Birmingham.As of pm, Capel Curig in Wales had experienced gusts of up to mph, with Emley Moore in Yorkshire seeing mph winds, while Drumalbin in Scotland was hit by mph gales.Social media users shared images and videos of fallen trees, large waves smashing coastal areas, howling winds and rain sweeping through quiet roads and dark and gloomy skies, with some facing delays on public transport.Met Office forecaster Greg Dewhurst told the PA news agency: “We’ve seen Storm Dudley move in over the course of today with strong winds and heavy rain across northern parts of the country. vw,vw,px, px"A rainbow over St Mary’s lighthouse in Whitley Bay “This is a complete contrast to areas in the south which have been rather mild and calm for the most part, the temperature even reaching C in some areas.“Exposed areas in Scotland, Northern Ireland, parts of Wales and northern England have seen wind speeds largely between  and mph but the worst affected areas have reached and even surpassed mph this afternoon.“In terms of rainfall the highest we’ve seen in the past  hours is .mm in Low Laithes in west Yorkshire, which is a good amount for the time period.“These conditions are likely to continue into the evening before mellowing out in the early hours of Thursday.” vw,vw,px, px"The Environment Agency has one flood warning in place as of Wednesday afternoon near the Lake District.East Midlands Railwayand London North Eastern Railwayhave warned customers to expect disruption to services in the coming days.ScotRail wound down almost all services from pm amid fears of falling trees and blowing debris as wind speeds are expected to reach more than mph.Ferries in Scotland have also been severely disrupted, with  of the  routes experiencing cancellations. vw,vw,px, px"Glasgow Central Station after trains and ferry services stopped running Historic Scotland announced the early closure of eight of its sites on Wednesday afternoon, including Edinburgh, Stirling and Blackness castles, Glasgow Cathedral, and Melrose Abbey.These conditions will be followed on Friday by Storm Eunice which could be even more damaging, with stronger winds than Dudley, heavy snow and possible blizzard conditions.Another amber warning has been issued, with the potential for stronger winds, and predictions that gusts could top mph in the South West and South Wales.The Environment Agency has warned of the risk of flooding to coastal areas in southern England on Friday. vw,vw,px, px"Flood duty manager Katharine Smith said: “Strong winds could bring coastal flooding to parts of the west, south-west and south coast of England, as well as the tidal River Severn, through the early hours of Friday morning and into the early afternoon.“This is due to Storm Eunice resulting in high waves and potential storm surge coinciding with the start of a period of spring tides.”She said agency teams were making preparations, erecting barriers and clearing screens where flood debris can build up.Do we expect windy conditions to continue Heres @aidanweather with our latest  Day Trend 👇 pic rXCkVPSU— Met OfficeFebruary , The Energy Networks Association has offered safety advice ahead of the storms.Spokesman Ross Easton said: “It’s really important to stay safe when bad weather hits. If you come across fallen power lines or damage to the electricity network, stay well clear and call  for free to report it. If there is an immediate risk to le or someone is in danger, dial .”Green Flag has predicted a spike in breakdowns across the country over the coming days.Mark Newberry, commercial director at Green Flag, said: “As a result of these weather conditions, we urge drivers to remain cautious and to carry out the relevant safety checks before setting off on their journeys.“It’s particularly important that people are as prepared as possible to withstand the high expected wind speeds and potential snow in some areas.”We want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: ending-free-covid-testing-mistake-sir-keir-starmer-says
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Covid testsSir Keir Starmer has said ending free coronavirus testing “is a mistake” which would increase the risk of Covid transmission.The Labour leader was commenting after reports first emerged on Tuesday that free lateral flowand PCR tests are set to be scrapped next week.The change would mean everyone – including vulnerable people, children and health and care workers – would have to pay to access tests for the virus, in plans first reported by LBC.On a visit to Birmingham’s Erdington constituency on Wednesday, ahead of a by-election there next month, Sir Keir said: “I think ending free testing is a mistake. vw,vw,px, px"Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer believes ending free testing would be an error “Covid isn’t going away.“Obviously all of us want restrictions to be release, but it’s still important that people testthey’ve got symptoms orthey’re going to see somebody who is particularly vulnerable.“Andyou take away free tests then that will diminish the likelihood of that and make it worse in the long run.”The ending of free testing is part of the Government’s “living with Covid” strategy, to be launched on Monday, according to LBC .It added that, going forward, it is believed the spread of the virus in the community will be monitored by surveillance schemes, such as from the Office for National Statistics .The Government previously said “universal free provision” of LFTs will come to an end at some stage, although it has said no decision has been taken on timings when responding to reports there could be an announcement on the ending of free testing next week.Last week, the Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced plans to remove all remaining measures in England a month early – from about February , when MPsto Parliament following the half-term break.Sir Keir said: “It’s not a good idea to get rid of free tests on the health grounds, nor is it economically the right thing to do.“I think inevitably they’ll be less tests but I do still think that as we go forward,people have symptoms, that they do need to test,they’re going to see someone who is particularly vulnerable, let’s say in a care home, it’ll be important to test.“So anything that reduces that is not good for health and it’s not good the economy in the long run.”We want our comments to be a lively and support as possible during these challenging times.Covid testsSir Keir Starmer has said ending free coronavirus testing “is a mistake” which would increase the risk of Covid transmission.The Labour leader was commenting after reports first emerged on Tuesday that free lateral flowand PCR tests are set to be scrapped next week.The change would mean everyone – including vulnerable people, children and health and care workers – would have to pay to access tests for the virus, in plans first reported by LBC.On a visit to Birmingham’s Erdington constituency on Wednesday, ahead of a by-election there next month, Sir Keir said: “I think ending free testing is a mistake. vw,vw,px, px"Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer believes ending free testing would be an error “Covid isn’t going away.“Obviously all of us want restrictions to be release, but it’s still important that people testthey’ve got symptoms orthey’re going to see somebody who is particularly vulnerable.“Andyou take away free tests then that will diminish the likelihood of that and make it worse in the long run.”The ending of free testing is part of the Government’s “living with Covid” strategy, to be launched on Monday, according to LBC .It added that, going forward, it is believed the spread of the virus in the community will be monitored by surveillance schemes, such as from the Office for National Statistics .The Government previously said “universal free provision” of LFTs will come to an end at some stage, although it has said no decision has been taken on timings when responding to reports title: sessions and sail to bring music to the swan later this year
story: An experience combining sailing and live music sessions will come to the isles for the first time in April. between th and th April.It will coincide with the th Shetland Folk Festival celebrations.The first voyage for Sessions and Sail took place in , but this is the first time it has been brought to the isles.Musician Nisbet said that the trip, initially booked for , had been #a long time coming#.#I’ve run trips further south and have always been keen to bring Sessions and Sail home,# he said. being such a well-known Shetland vessel, and having sailed on her regularly myself, I know she will be the perfect boat to partner with.#I am also delighted that for the sailing we will be under the command of skipper Maggie Adamson, who is a top class Shetland musician as well as an excellent sailor.#Swan Trust Trustee Brian Wishart said they were #delighted# to bring Sessions and Sail to the isles. is no stranger to musical sessions, with many a memorable night aboard.#We hope this trip may become an annual event, adding to the wide range of high-quality musical experiences on offer in Shetland.#..Twelve young Shetlanders will take part in the Tall Ships Races  which set off from Aalborg in Denmark next month.A group of  youngsters set off for an adventure of sailing and racing on board the Swan this afternoon – their first destination Hirtshals#Keen sailor Scott Sandison saw off global competition to be named Sail Training International Sail Trainer of the Year .Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: wirdle is the word of the week
story: It is the web-based word game that has taken the world by storm, but now a Shetland version of Wordle has made an appearance.#Wirdle# follows the same basic rules as the original game, but challenges the player to identy a Shetland dialect word instead., which describes itself as #a gadderie# dedicated to studying, describing and documenting dialect, or #Shaetlan#.For the uninitiated, Wordle gives players six attempts to guess a five-letter word, with feedback given for each guess in the form of coloured tiles.The colours of the tiles indicade when letters match or, with even more luck, actually occupy the correct position.But for those who know the dference between a #spret# and the #dorts#, Wirdle might provide an ideal dialect-based alternative...Ryan Taylor has worked as a reporter since , and has been at The Shetland Times since , covering a wide iety of news topics.Before then he reported for other newspapers in the Highlands, where he was raised, and in Fe, where he began his career with DC Thomson. He also has experience in broadcast journalism with Grampian Television. He has lived in Shetland since , where he harbours an unhealthy interest in old cars and motorbikes.A Brae High School pupil has been nominated for a new award celebrating the best of Scottish dialect.A new manual to help children and adults with communication dficulties has been launched for the isles.The promoters of the Rhoda Bulter Award are reminding anyone planning to take part in this year#s competition that there are just over three weeks#Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: one in three shetland homes to be tidal powered by new array
story: A new tidal energy scheme is hoped to power a third of all Shetland’s homes, confirming its role “at the forefront of the green energy revolution”.Nova Innovation, which built the world’s first tidal array at Bluemull Sound in , has todayannounced plans for its largest ever development at Yell Sound.The tidal pioneers said the new MW array between Yell and Bigga would build on its success in transforming the “raw power of the North Atlantic into clean, predictable energy, powering Shetland’s homes, businesses and grid”.It would be almost four times as powerful as the existing array at Bluemull Sound.Nova’s chief executive Simon Forrest said: “Having been at the centre of the oil and gas industry for  years, Shetland is now at the forefront of the green energy revolution, and we are excited to play our part in decarbonising the Shetland Islands.”Mr Forrest said he was “delighted to be working with local partners to deliver another world-leading project.”Nova has already been using Shetland companies to manufacture turbine blades, steel structures and provide vessels and services.The new turbines, which will be manufactured at Nova’s facility in Edinburgh, sit on the seabed, so there is no visual impact and ships can pass above them.The company claims environmental monitoring of its Bluemull turbines show they “work in harmony with marine wildle”.The Scottish government’s cabinet secretary for net zero and energy Michael Matheson said the development marked another important milestone in commercialising tidal energy in Scotland.Mr Matheson said it would put Shetland “at the heart of this exciting technology#.“With our abundant natural resources and expertise, Scotland is ideally placed to harness the global market for marine energy whilst helping deliver a net-zero economy both here and across the world,# he added.Nova said its Shetland projects proved tidal energy can generate substantial levels of clean energy for coastal populations.Crown Estate Scotland , which granted Nova permission to develop on the seabed, said it was pleased to help island communities decarbonise their energy systems.Head of emerging technology at CES Sian Wilson added: “It’s important for Scotland to have a erse renewable energy supply to deliver on the country’s net zero ambitions in the coming decades and predictable tidal power at scale will play a valuable part in achieving that goal.”Ive been a reporter since  at newspapers in Lincolnshire and East Anglia. Before joining The Shetland Times, I was part of Archants Investigations Unit, reporting for titles across the group. When not at work, Im usually reading books, listening to records or walking around the countryside.Another  cases of coronavirus have been recorded in Shetland, according to the latest Scottish government figures today [Wednesday].Councillors have voted in favour of a freeze on council tax and housing rent following calls to address the rising cost of living.It is the web-based word game that has taken the world by storm, but now a Shetland version of Wordle has made an appearance.Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: tobar an dualchais brides day the birthday of
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na Daoine or ‘the dead month’.   or Saint Bride’s Day. This falls in with ‘Candlemas’ on nd February as a Christian festival and a traditional end of the Christmas season. Candlemas commemorates the presentation of the infant Jesus at the Temple in Jerusalem as described in St Luke’s Gospel and when some denominations bring candles to their church. Candlemas is also one of the so-called ‘Quarter-days’ marking the changing seasons of winter, spring, summer and autumn. It is followed by Whitsun, Lammas Day and Martinmas as the term-days with their administrative and legal implications for the payment of rents and flittings. Saint Bride or Saint Bridget has been one of the most popular of the saints of the celtic church. Of course, there were many ‘Bridgets’, but the one whose festival date is on st February was ‘Bridget of Kildare’ in Leinster whose death was dated to AD . Bridget was one of the patron saints of Ireland and is remembered in the tradition of plaiting rush crosses around st February to set over doors and windows to protect the home from fire and other danger.   or the endearing ‘Bride’s little fosterling’.’ . ‘Bride’s Day, the birthday of spring’. century, traditions of Saint Bride were collected by Alexander Carmichael among his prayers, hymns, blessings and charms from the Hebrides. He suggests that accounts of Saint Bride were not easily recovered and summarised the tradition: ‘The serpent is supposed to emerge from its hollow among the hills on St Bride’s Day, and a propitiatory hymn was sung to it. Only one verse of this hymn has been obtained, apparently the first. It dfers in dferent localities: [Early on Bride’s mornThe serpent shall come from the hole, I shall not molest the serpent, Nor will the serpent molest me.’ The snake is a powerful element in mythology and religion and a creature to be respected as the ‘hymn’ makes clear. Familiar in the snake coiled round the rod, it is a symbol of medicine and healing, and the appearance of the adder or snake on Saint Bride’s Day offers a feeling of hope and transformation, and of turning the corner with the ening of the days. . century. .!... !

title: special donnie munro concert to bring skye live back with a
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineThe island#s premier music festival is set toin style on Thursday th May # following a two-year break due to the pandemic # with an opening night extravaganza # ‘Coming Home: An Evening with Donnie Munro and friends’ and featuring special guests in the form of multi-award-winning Gaelic supergroup Mànran.The show will be Donnie’s first in his hometown since  and will see him perform with a full eight-piece band line-up on the spectacular Skye Live Festival site at Am Meall in Portree. The singer said: #This offers me a fantastic opportunity to bring this amazing line-up, featuring some of Scotland’s top musicians together, for an exclusive performance to open this year’s Skye Live Festival.He added: #It has been fantastic to watch the festival grow in strength, year on year, in what must be one of the most special and unique festival locations anywhere in the world, and to see it become internationally recognised as, ‘one of the best boutique festivals in the country’, is just fantastic for the island, and it is such a great honour for me to be invited to be a part of it all and to be bringing the music back home here to where it all began.#Joining Donnie Munro on the night will be Mànran, internationally recognised as one of the most iconic and respected Scottish bands on the road today. With three hugely successful studio albums under their belt, in October  the band released their fourth, titled ÙRAR to critical acclaim, and adding to their success, lead female vocalist, Kim Carnie was crowned ‘Gaelic Singer of the Year’ at the  Hands up for Trad Awards.Mànran founder and accordionist Gary Innes said: #Playing on the Isle of Skye has always been a special night for Mànran over the years but joining Donnie and his band as their special guests for Skye Live will certainly be a night to remember.#.

title: island couple fly the flag for skye in
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineA Skye couple who are embarking on a trip of a letime in Antarctica have proudly flown the official island flag this week while camping at the earth#s southernmost continent.Melanie and Bob Mossfrom Camastianavaig, near Portree, left the island on th January in the first leg of an epic journey which saw them arrive late last week at the landmass which is almost wholly ice-covered, spans . million kilometres, and is located more than , miles south of Skye.Speaking to the Free Press from their camp at Kerr Point, Melanie detailed her and Bob#s incredible voyage so far.She said: #On the th January we flew to Santiago, Chile and arrived in mid-morning of the th. We stayed in quarantine overnight . On the th we flew from Santiago south to Punta Arenas at the tip of Chile to meet our ship.#Melanie and Bob are sailing on the MS Roald Amundsen which is a Hybrid powered expedition ship owned by the Norwegian company Hurtigruten.#We are at sea for  days in total, exploring the Antarctic Peninsula,# she said.#We aren#t exactly known for traditional beach holidays on the Costas, so this voyage was perfect for us. Going to rarely visited places at the end of the earth, to see things only a few other people have ever seen.“It also helps I love penguins.”Melanie said that by sailing by expedition ship, they had the opportunity to explore remote parts of Antarctica on foot and from small zodiac boats, getting close to nature and the beautul wilderness.She added: #We are one of the very few passenger ships to get below the Antarctic Circle this season, so it was a privilege to spend three days down there. The photo of me holding the flag on the balcony below the Antarctic Circle at .° south.#Earlier this week, Melanie alerted the Free Press about their adventure asking: #@WHFP do you know how far any of the fantastic new Skye Flags have travelled  Ours left Camustianavaig with us last month and crossed the Antarctic Circle to ° South and last night we camped with it at Kerr Point Antarctica ° South.#Melanie explained: #I took the flag as it hangs in my ‘den’ at home and when I was researching the trip it was always catching my eye.#It dawned on me one day that I#d be travelling further south than Skye is north and I should take the flag with us. When Bob and I got the opportunity to camp at Kerr Point ° south we just had to fly the flag proudly.”She added: #Only  guests had the opportunity to camp the night in Antarctica, so we were very lucky. Our camp neighbours were from Germany and asked us about the flag as they did not recognise it. We were very proud to explain where we came from and how new the flag is to the Isle of Skye.#I also work seasonally as an instructor at ACE Target Sports, Portree and we have photos of playing cards customers have won at ACE and taken with them around the world. I have taken a couple of ACE#S with me, taken photos and sent them back to Mattto add to the album! So, we are flying the flag for ACE as well.#Melanie and Bob are due to arrive back on Skye next Wednesday #All in all, an epic trip, never to be forgotten and full of amazing memories. Even the eye-wateringly cold Antarctic plunges we have both done down here!# she addedThe couple#s flying of the Skye standard will no doubt be a proud moment for young islander Calum Alasdair Munro from Kilmuir. The youngster’s design was selected as the official flag following a competition which lasted  months, attracted  entries and received more than , public votes.Calum Alasdair raised the flag at an official and socially distant unfurling ceremony at the Nicolson memorial in August .

title: centenary sailor dolan caps his 100th birthday in
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineA resident in An Acarsaid care home in Broadford, Skye, ‘Dolan’ as he is known, was asked by staff what he wanted for his special birthday He was proud to wear his answer at Armadale Pier, where he was greeted on the MV Loch Nevis by master and fellow Lewisman Iain Mackenzie, who lives in Kyleakin.As well as the cap, Dolan was also given a bag of CalMac goodies. February  at Flesherin, Point, Dolan worked with his dad making Harris Tweed before getting an apprenticeship with a bakery in Stornoway.However, his ambition was always to join the Merchant Navy, which he did in  in Glasgow.Not long after, he joined the crew of the British-India ship SS Manela which sailed to South Africa during World War Two.Dolan said: “I also went to America, Canada and Australia while at sea and could be away for up to two years at a time, but it was always great to get on the boat in Glasgow and head home to Lewis.“I ed to Lewis for a time after the war and spent many happy years living with my sister Mary Ann down in Back. I loved going down to the pier and watching the ferries come and go when we went to town, many a journey I enjoyed with CalMac.#I have a small picture of the #Sulivan# in my room # the sea and boats have always given me so much joy.”Master Mackenzie added: “It was a pleasure to help Dolan mark his special birthday, we were delighted to welcome him on board.#He is a really interesting character who has travelled the world, and me and the crew were privileged to talk to him and listen to his wonderful stories.#I am from Aird, a nearby village in Point, and it was my pleasure to present the hat and goodies to a fellow rubhach.”Last Sunday , Dolan enjoyed his birthday party in An Acarsaid, surrounded by family and friends and delighted members of staff. The Lord Lieutenant of Ross and Cromarty, Joanie Whiteford, also visited as Dolan received his card from the Queen.Care home manager Margaret Mackinnon told the Free Press it is a pleasure to have Dolan staying in An Acarsaid.“He loves good banter and is keen on his music,” she added. “He plays the mouth organ and the piano and especially loves listening and dancing to ceilidh music. He also loves listening to the accordion.#He is a huge character with us here at An Acarsaid and has a quiet, happy outlook on le.#He enjoys his Golden Virginia smokes and a nice dram. Dolan participates in all our activities and remains a very competitive dominoes player. He loves to win and is loved by all.”

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220214news56 of ni pet owners would ditch their partners for their pets
story: Men have been warned to be on their best behaviour on Valentine’s Day or face a visit to the dog house, according to a survey of pet owners and their relationships. Women are more likely to ditch their partner than their pet, found a poll for nationwide pet retailer Jollyes. Asked about their relationship with their partner and their pet and which one they would ditch first,  per cent said they would ditch their partner against  per cent who would ditch their pet. Men were more loyal to their partners, with  per cent saying they would ditch their pet and  per cent saying they would ditch their partner. Overall,  per cent would ditch their partner first and  per cent said the pet would go first. The study was carried out by Jollyes to gauge humans’ attitudes to romance and relationships as it launches the search on social media for a canine couple to take part in a romantic dinner for two at its doggy dates diner, “C’est Jollyes”, open for one day only on  February at its Runcorn store in Cheshire . Two dogs will get the chance to enjoy a three course dinner featuring a menu from Jollyes Artisan Lestage range including angus beef with sweet potato, venison and salmon, and duck with sweet potato. The survey showed some big dferences in attitudes to pets and partners around the UK. People in North East England were more likely to ditch their partnerover their pet, followed by London , Northern Ireland , South West . [See table in editor’s notes below for regional breakdown.] Owners were asked what they loved most about their pets, with loyalty, unconditional love, loving nature, affection and a warm heart among the qualities cited. No matter how much love an animal gives, most pet ownerswould prefer a romantic Valentine’s night with their partner than one spent with their pet. Of male respondents,  per cent chose a night with their partner, compared with  per cent of female respondents. The figures were broadly similar across the country. Among the other popular traits cited by pet owners were: “they are so loyal and loving. And cute!” “unconditional love and loyalty” “they comfort me when I’m feeling blue” “doesnt argue or answer back” “they always cheer me up” “waggy tail and warm heart” and “her loving nature, always there for me when I need her”. One said: “Sometimes playful, sometimes cuddly, intelligent, independent, sometimes dangerous. All rather like my partner really.” Not everyone was totally enamoured with their pet. One said: “Nothing, it hates me, only loves my we”. And not all pets’ traits would make for a romantic night out – one said: “hassle free”, another said “doesn’t answer back” and one said “it’s a tortoise and he’s as indferent to use as we are to him”. Phil Turner-Naylor, head of marketing at Jollyes, said: “We’re known as a nation of animal lovers and this goes to prove it. When it comes to relationships, a lot people would choose their pet over their partner. “The good news for romantics though is that a big majority choose people over pets. What it does show, especially for men, is that partners have to work hard to keep the romance going or they might find themselves in the dog house. Women are looking for a romantic night with their partner on Valentine’s, butthe men don’t get it right, they had better watch out.”

Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownEducationTransfer TestsGraduationsBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium School leaders ‘don’t have guidance and are having to make decisions in the dark’ after curb removalsExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseSchool leaders are concerned as students prepare toafter the half-term break FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSchool leaders are concerned as students prepare toafter the half-term breakMark BainTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailSchools have yet to receive any further guidance following the removal of Covid- restrictions, with head teachers left unsure on whether mitigations should stay in place when pupilsafter the half-term break.The Department of Education said it is still “considering the detail” after restrictions in wider society were removed by Health Minister Robin Swann earlier this week.Read MoreTeachers ‘ready to strike’ after rejecting pay offerCurbs such as the wearing of masks are no longer in place, but the situation for schools remains unclear. Mitigations have included advice for post-primary pupils to wear face coverings at all times when inside school buildings and for schools to introduce one-way systems.“We will be writing out to schools in the coming days in relation to any impact this may have on the department’s current Covid guidance,” the department said.But the timing of the removal of restrictions, while schools are on half-term break, means head teachers have been left in the dark on what will be expected when they .“We just don’t knowcoronavirus mitigations will be in place,” said Graham Gault, interim director of the National Association of Head Teachers.“Principals have been left trying their best to address the concerns of pupils, parents and staff while we again wait for guidance from the Department of Education.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “While the lting of restrictions in wider society is celebrated, the truth for schools is that they will continue to mitigate against coronavirus in order to keep as many children and staff in school as possible. Schools will definitely not be back to normal next week.“This is yet another school break which is tinted by the fact that school leaders don’t have guidance and are having to make decisions in the dark. We have advised our members to always err on the side of safety.”One of the main concerns is that the removal of restrictions in society will lead to a sharp increase in Covid cases, which in turn will lead to further problems with staff absent from the classroom.“The great fear among school leaders is that the lting of restrictions will further increase the crisis of trying to find available staff and keep schools open,” said Mr Gault.“There are many across our schools feeling a bit of trepidation at what increased community transmission might mean for keeping schools open. What we need is clear guidance from the minister so we can prepare for what will be asked of us.”While the number of reported Covid cases among school pupils in the first week of February fell to just over ,, the figures over a -day period, since schools ed after Christmas, have shown a signicant rise in positive cases.Related topicsDepartment of EducationDepartment of HealthMore On Department of title: teachers ready to strike after rejecting pay offer
story: Michelle McIlveen during her first engagement as Northern Ireland Minister for Education visiting Ballysillan Primary School and Nursery in north Belfast.PAJustin McCamphill, Northern Officiall with teaching union NASUWT.***School budget problems** Maghaberry Primary School principal Graham Gault who claims schools struggling with budget over lack of leadership with no Stormont. Pic by Peter Morrison FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueMichelle McIlveen during her first engagement as Northern Ireland Minister for Education visiting Ballysillan Primary School and Nursery in north Belfast.Mark BainTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailTeachers have rejected the latest pay offer by employers and Department of Education with the NASUWT union warning that % of its membership were now prepared to take strike action.Education Minister Michelle McIlveen said she was disappointed with a lack of progress in pay negotiations.Read MoreSchool leaders ‘don’t have guidance and are having to make decisions in the dark’ after curb removals“Management Side had offered a two-year pay deal worth .% from  September ,” the Minister said.“The pay award would have seen the removal of the bottom point of the current teachers’ pay scale and the addition of a further point at the top of the scale, with a similar approach applied to each of the pay ranges for school leaders.“This pay offer had been made despite a very dficult financial situation and I had hoped that this would have led to a completion of the pay negotiations for   and   during the current mandate. Management Side will now take time to consider how the matter should be progressed before engaging again with NITC.”NASUWT confirmed the offer had been rejected by % of its members, not accepting that the deal for  to  proposed by employers was a .% pay increase.The highest rise would be for newly qualied teachers as under the proposals a new teacher’s starting salary would rise to £, from about £, with a newly qualied teacher seeing their gross salary increase by .% from September  with no increase in September .Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Unions claim that most teachers would receive much smaller increases over two years and that the figure of .% presented by the employers included the normal incremental pay progression teachers were due to get anyway.“The anger felt by the profession could not be more stark with the vast majority of members saying they were prepared to take industrial action over the offer, with % prepared to take action short of strike action and % prepared to take strike action,” the NASUWT said.“The vast majority of NASUWT members also expressed concerns about the failure of the Department of Education and the employers to deliver on the  Agreement, with % saying that their workload had increased signicantly in the last two years.“And in a sign of the retention challenges facing the profession, % said they were seriously considering leaving teaching.Dr Patrick Roach, NASUWT General Secretary added: “This pay offer has come after months and months of delay and represents a further damaging real-terms cut to teachers’ salaries at a time of surging inflation and a deepening cost of living crisis.“Members are clear that they are prepared to take actionthe Minister does not deliver a substantially better deal which addresses teachers’ concerns on pay and workload.”Justin McCamphill, NASUWT National Official Northern Ireland, said the “derisory” offer is “damaging the morale of the profession. It will only serve to make the recruitment and retention of teachers harder at a time when they are desperately needed.”The Northern Ireland Teachers’ Councilhad submitted a pay claim for % for  to  and has called on the Department to urgently make a new offer “which reflects the current inflationary environment.”School leaders’ union NAHT has called for further negotiations after % of NAHT members in Northern Ireland also voted to turn down the offer.Graham Gault, Interim Director for NAHT NI, said: “Having endured cumulative real-terms pay decreases worth % over the last decade, school leaders have made their opinions on the Department’s recent pay offer clear through our democratic processes. A basic cost-of-living increase for teachers and school leaders was requested through the NITC , but the offer has fallen well short.“We believe that genuine attempts to resolve this issue can result in an acceptable settlement and are determined to do all that we can to avoid any escalation to a formal pay dispute.”The chair of the Irish National Teachers’ OrganisationNorthern Committee, Ms Marie O’Shea added: “The latest offer made by the management side to the unions for a cost-of-living increase in the   year falls signicantly short of both our expectations and that of our members.“For any offer to be acceptable to our membership, it must reflect the ongoing efforts by our members who, during the Covid- pandemic, ensured that the vital routine of the education system, remained working effectively for the children and young people in their care. Any award offered to teachers needs to reflect this and offset the effects of the rising inflation we are currently experiencing.”“We remain available to discuss these matters with them constructively and hope they will approach this issue with a more positive and practical attitude than this offer would suggest they have brought to the issue of teachers’ pay to date.”Related topicsDepartment of title: children aged 5 to 11 in northern ireland to be offered covid
story: Stock image FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueStock imageChristopher LeebodyTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailChildren in Northern Ireland who are aged between  to -years-of-age and not in a clinical risk group will be offered the chance to receive a Covid- jab.The announcement by Robin Swann follows the latest advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation .It also comes after Wales, Scotland and England also announced they would be following JCVI guidance.Those children eligible will be offered two  mcg doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech jab, with an interval of at least  weeks between doses.Read MoreCoronavirus Northern Ireland: Five deaths and , new casesThe dose offered to these children will be equivalent to a third of the strength given to a typical adult.In December, the JCVI had advised that children aged five to  years who were in a clinical risk group, or who were a household contact of someone who is immunosuppressed, should be offered vaccines.Mr Swann said: As has always been the case, our vaccination programme will continue to be guided by the expert advice.This announcement by the JCVI underlines the important role that the Covid- vaccines plays in protecting people of all ages and has only been taken after rigorous assessment of both safety and effectiveness.I have asked the PHAto work with thetrusts to put this latest advice into operation and further details will be released shortly.In a statement, the JCVI said: This advice on the offer of vaccination to  to -year-olds who are not in a clinical risk group is considered by JCVI as a one-off pandemic response programme.As the Covid- pandemic moves further towards endemicity in the UK, JCVI will review whether, in the longer term, an offer of vaccination to this, and other paediatric age groups, continues to be advised.Related topicsRobin SwannMore On Robin SwannBusinesses annoyed work from home guidance Credit: Liam McBurney PA Wire FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueProtection: A young woman puts on her mask as she walks past a Covid- safety message in Belfast city centre. Credit: Liam McBurney PA WireFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailWhen the books are written and history students look back on the early s, they’ll be forgiven for thinking they’re studying science fiction instead.Had a man with a sandwich board been shouting “the end is nigh” outside Belfast City Hall in February , it would have looked like he had a point. It was the end of the world as we knew it.Read MoreNiamh Campbell:OpinionImportant day forto some kind of normalityNorthern Ireland’s Covid rules scrapped and replaced with guidance“The end is nigh” means something dferent today, and we can all breathe a little easier.There is no doubt that without the restrictions we would be looking back on a lot more lives lost to Covid than the official figure of over ,.For many, their last moments were spent alone. For those who mourned, they watched from afar. That was one of the hardest restrictions to bear.Pulling our bedroom curtains closed on Monday, March , , we did so wondering what sort of world would await when we opened them the next morning.The UK death toll stood at , three of them here.St Patrick’s Day had already been cancelled, giving the first hint of what was heading our direction. Then lockdown started.Farewells were said to those in nursing homes as the doors closed to visits. Businesses shut, save for those deemed essential.The queues outside supermarkets started. Our children spent their first day at home after the closure of schools.That was  days ago.We had all suspected it was coming, having watched images from around the world as the pandemic wave approached our shores.Shielding letters were sent to , of the most vulnerable, telling how they were to go into isolation.March ,  was furlough day as the Government committed to support % of wages for employees.Three days later gatherings of more than two people were banned. It was essential trips only.Thursday, March  saw the start of a weekly ritual as we clapped for carers. Communities made scrubs and masks for front line workers. On a bigger scale, companies were redeploying staff and taking on new workers to help the cause as fears over a lack of PPE rose.Then, at pm on Saturday, March  lockdown officially commenced.We said farewell to work colleagues, socially distanced ourselves from family and friends, and started to embrace a new style of community.Those of us with children became teachers overnight. Our children taught us a thing or two also, with crash courses on Zoom, Facetime and TikTok.The older generation had to embrace the technology the young had grown up with. Hands upyou logged in to a Zoom meeting hiding those pyjama bottoms under the kitchen table Maybe it was just as well for our egos the pubs and nightclubs were closed. Self-styled hair, out of necessity, was perhaps not the way to go.Strange as it may seem, being apart from other people actually brought us closer together.For the older among us, we instantly felt a need to hug our parents as soon as we were told we couldn’t. It would be a shame not to remember that. In a way, we all became heroes of a sort. “Stay at home, save lives,” was the message. We stayed at home, while others manned the front line.Driving around was an eerie experience in those early days — few cars on the road shops shut.And when we went out for a walk to get some exercise we actually heard the birdsong.Weddings were halted. Birthdays went uncelebrated. Holidays put on hold.And in the midst of all the sitting around doing not very much at all, a new vocabulary sprung up: furlough the R-rate PPE self-isolation shielding.Social distancing was no longer the domain of the school disco, where the boys sat on one side and the girls on the other.We all wanted to knowwe were a key worker. There was the unprecedented rolling out of guidelines, restrictions, support services and grants to keep businesses afloat.Confusion reigned: how many could meet in a garden  Where could airplanes take us to, and what did we need to get there  What was a ‘wet’ pub Little by little, the restrictions we were living with eased and chinks of light started to emerge.Cemeteries reopened on April  after a public outcry — the first easing of curbs.Monday, May  saw garden centres reopen, with the promise of more rules being ltedthe downward trend in cases of Covid continued.All eyes were on the R-rate, but the same day saw the first signs of a lockdown breakdown.By the end of the month, with temperatures soaring, thousands headed for the seaside.Still, on May , for the first time since March , no deaths were recorded. Positive signs were emerging, and further lockdown easements saw le edging back, evenit was baby steps.But there were relapses. We were teased with the freedom of the pre-pandemic world, only to have it pulled back from us as new iants, second waves of the virus, kept arriving.Restrictions came, then were eased. But they never went away.For many, particularly in the business world, there has been a heavy price to pay.Some pub doors were shut, never to open again. Even big names such as Debenhams could not survive the pandemic, having battled for years against the growth in online retailing.Then there was the impact on people’s wellbeing.That many died having contracted Covid has been well documented, but lockdown brought with it the extra baggage of isolation. The mental state of people was a constant concern.Sure, it’ll be over by Christmas, we said in . We said the same in .It wouldn’t be this placethe ending of restrictions didn’t bring with it some added confusion and doubt.With the Executive unable to meet due to the lack of a First and Deputy First Minister, the issue became a legal matter.In years to come there’ll be plenty of stories told starting with the words: “Do you remember the time ”Those history books  years from now will be filled with the facts and the figures, the bumps in the road, the scandals of those in public office.But we’ve lived with it all, lived through it all, and come out the other side.We can all see a little more clearly now.The dark clouds have been replaced by that hopeful rainbow we’ve been teased with several times over the past two years.There does come a time when we have to learn to live in the world as it is, as close as we can to the way we did.We might not be quite stepping into the brightest of bright days.Restrictions will change to guidelines and recommendations.There will still be many content to take the precautions they feel they need, and everyone should move forward at their own pace.Hopefully the last two years have taught the majority of us to appreciate the things in our lives that are most important to us — our family and friends.Le moves fast. Hopefully, before long, the darkest days of Covid will be a memory.Being honest, a lot of people had left those memories behind some time ago.But think, too, of those who bring the memory of loved ones lost into a world their parent, husband, we, sister or brother is not there to enjoy beside them.Related topicsBelfast City CouncilMore On Belfast City CouncilNI cinema owner calls on Belfast title: demolition of former kincora boys home gets green light
story: The former Kincora Boys# Home FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe former Kincora Boys# HomeNiamh CampbellTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe demolition of the former Belfast boys’ home Kincora has officially been given the green light by Belfast City Council.It’s now believed that while a date has not been specied for the demolition, it’s hoped it will take place “sooner rather than later”, according to East Belfast MP Gavin Robinson. East Belfast MP Gavin Robinson welcomed the official confirmation following a meeting on Tuesday night. Read More‘Robert was getting too close to exposing evil’​​​​​​​ Read MoreWe know what happened in Kincora boys# home and we want the files open, insists victimThree members of staff were convicted in  of sexual abuse of boys in the Upper Newtownards Road home, though claims of state collusion were rejected by the Historical Institutional Abuse Inquiry.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The Belfastrevealed in April last year, that the building was to be demolished and the site turned into apartments in a £.m project by Hagan Homes, who said they’re “very aware of the sensitivities” surrounding the home.The timescale of when the building will be destroyed “will be a matter for the developer,” Mr Robinson added.There has been some history of planning applications to the site and at one stage the council wanted to retain the building for its architectural merit,” said the DUP politician.I thought that was an appalling position, but I’m pleased they changed tack.”Taking to Twitter on Wednesday, he posted: “After years of campaigning by victims and survivors, I#m pleased to learn the former Kincora Boys home will be razed to the ground.”After years of campaigning by victims and survivors, I#m pleased to learn the former Kincora Boys home will be razed to the ground.— Gavin RobinsonFebruary , Kincora Boys# Home was set up in  to provide full-time accommodation for teenage boys but closed in  following the exposure of sexual abuse by staff.The scandal shocked Northern Ireland when it emerged in  that at least  boys were sexually abused at the care home.Three senior staff members - former housemaster William McGrath, Joseph Mains and William Semple - were jailed in  for abusing  boys.But there have also been allegations of state collusion in the abuse, and of the involvement of high-ranking establishment figures.Kincora Boys# Home was examined in the Historical Institutional Abuse Inquiry in . The inquiry heard that boys who#d just arrived to the home would be warned about McGrath.Chairman, the late Sir Anthony Hart, said sexual abuse had taken place at the home though the inquiry dismissed claims that senior politicians, civil servants and businessmen were complicit in a paedophile ring.Sir Anthony said: It was not a homosexual brothel, nor was it used by any of the security agencies as a honey pot to entrap, blackmail or otherwise exploit homosexuals.He added: It is now time to finally lay these unfounded myths to rest.At least  files directly related to the home are #closed# to the public, and in one case the order remains in place until  at the earliest.Around a dozen are closed - either fully or partially - until the mid-s and beyond.The building on Upper Newtownards Road was put on the market in August  for £,. Its owner at the time, Leslie Black, had renamed it Linden House and used it as offices.His company had plans to refurbish the building but in , then First Minister Peter Robinson called for it to be razed, which Mr Black said meant he had to abandon his plan. He instead applied for planning application for  apartments on the site. But that development did not go ahead.Most ReadCommunity heartbroken after Co Down man Kevin Gregory dies suddenly in UkraineStorm Dudley: Weather warning brought forwardCivil servants set for hybrid title: hargey blasts farcical claims of sectarian approach to stadia funding
story: Sinn Fein’s Deirdre Hargey  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSinn Fein’s Deirdre Hargey By David Young, PAFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA Sinn Fein minister has dismissed as “farcical” claims she has adopted a sectarian approach to sports funding.Communities Minister Deidre Hargey was responding to a claim by DUP MLA Paul Frew, who heavily criticised a decision to halt a scheme to upgrade football stadia while continuing the redevelopment of the GAA’s Casement Park.In the Assembly on Tuesday, former economy minister Mr Frew accused Ms Hargey and Finance Minister Conor Murphy of making “sectarian decisions” as he claimed they were treating one project dferently to the other.The controversy flared after Ms Hargey announced that she was unable to progress the £. million programme to redevelop local sub-regional football stadia due to the absence of a ing executive."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland fc .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_faaf-cf-dc-d-babc_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland fc .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_faaf-cf-dc-d-babc_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland fc .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_faaf-cf-dc-d-babc_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland fc .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_faaf-cf-dc-d-babc_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Casement Park in Belfast is in line for a major redevelopment PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCasement Park in Belfast is in line for a major redevelopment She claims while the funding has been secured for the initiative, the approval of the wider Executive is required before it can progress to allocating funding for projects at specic grounds.Ms Hargey has blamed the DUP for the situation, claiming the party’s decision to pull Paul Givan out of the first minister’s role meant the stadia programme had to be placed on hold until a ing administration is back in place.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The DUP has disputed this position and contrasted it with the minister’s insistence that the redevelopment of the GAA’s Casement Park in west Belfast can continue despite the Stormont crisis.Ms Hargey insists the two projects are at dferent stages of progression, with the Casement redevelopment a live project that had been approved by the Executive, while the sub regional stadia programme had not reached the stage of identying what works would be undertaken.She said she has always made it clear that Executive approval would be needed before progressing the sub regional stadia programme to roll out."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland b .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_faaf-cf-dc-d-babc_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland b .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_faaf-cf-dc-d-babc_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland b .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_faaf-cf-dc-d-babc_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland b .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_faaf-cf-dc-d-babc_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "DUP MLA for north Antrim Paul Frew PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDUP MLA for north Antrim Paul Frew On Wednesday, the minister was asked by reporters to respond to Mr Frew’s claim.“Well, I think it’s farcical,” she said.“It’s just a mistruth to begin with. I’ve worked very well with the IFAand indeed with all sporting codes from when I came into post, I’ve engaged them on a regular basis.“They actually worked very closely with me throughout the pandemic, in not just stabilising those sectors, but also working to address the needs of the community through food parcels and through prescriptions.“This is not a sectarian issue and it’s not a Casement versus sub-regional.“I think it is important to say that the funding for both programmes is secure and the Finance Minister laid that out.“My brother runs a local football team in my local community, I see the impact of soccer and indeed all sports. My focus now is making sure that we have an executive that I can bring these proposals to and that we get that money out into sports clubs without delay.”She added: “The DUP chose to walk away from that executive, when they knew all of these issues were outstanding and, for me, that was for their own party political interests.“That is hugely regrettable because we’re seeing the impact of that decision, not just on sports.”Most ReadCommunity heartbroken after Co Down man Kevin Gregory dies suddenly in UkraineStorm Dudley: Weather warning brought forwardCivil servants set for hybrid working Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium ‘I dreaded going to work… but I’m totally vindicated, the truth has come out’ – woman who won £k Army harassment case speaks outExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseBronagh Murray with her lawyer Brian ArcherThiepval BarracksBronagh Murray: Photo by Matt Mackey   Press Eye. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueBronagh Murray with her lawyer Brian ArcherAllan PrestonTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA Co Down woman who won a religious and sexual discrimination case against the Ministry of Defencehas told of how months of insults by an Army captain left her dreading the thought of going to work.Bronagh Murray , a Catholic civilian worker who was stationed in Thiepval Barracks in Lisburn, is set to receive over £, in compensation after the decision of a Fair Employment Tribunal in Belfast this week. It is believed to be one of the largest awards of its kind, with the MoD also accepting liability.Read MoreCatholic woman who left job over alleged harassment by her Army boss to receive more than £, compensationSpeaking to the Belfast , Ms Murray said she was relieved at the decision and was now focused on rebuilding her le.I absolutely dreaded going to work even though I had an immaculate record as a civil servant since I was , she said.“At times I just couldn’t think straight. I thought I had a handle on it by ignoring him but I obviously didn’t. I kept thinking, ‘he’s getting the message, it just needs to stop’. I didn’t approach him at the time about the harassment because I felt I wouldn’t be believed and it would lead to more harassment because I didn’t find him funny.The harassment by the Army captain, who cannot be named for security reasons, took place over a five-month period in , with Ms Murray later retiring due to deteriorating psychiatric condition in .Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The tribunal heard that the captain repeatedly referenced her religion in front of others and had also referred to her as “the big cougar”.In one incident, he was reported to have said: “I need back up, I have an Irish Catholic girl armed and dangerous, come quick, need help.”During an office conversation about a concert, it’s also claimed that he said: “I bet you have tried to steal a cone, that is the Catholic coming out in you.”After starting the complaint process in September , the captain was eventually disciplined and transferred to another military posting.The tribunal awarded Ms Murray around £, to cover injury to feelings, psychiatric injuries, loss of previous earnings and interest. Not due to retire until , compensation for loss of future earnings was calculated in excess of £,.She added: “I’m just so relieved and pleased with the outcome. I feel great because I’m totally vindicated and at long last the truth has come out.”She said the admission of liability from the MoD was particularly important.I didn’t ask for any of this, I had every intention of working until retirement age. Because of what happened to me, my health broke down and I was left with no other option than to go through the process of ill health retirement.“It was just so stressful, it was a horrible feeling. I had confided in a few close friends who knew what I was going through. It was such a hard time.”She said finding the courage to eventually speak up had felt like a major risk at the time.“I was afraid I wouldn’t be taken seriously, especially the cougar comment, she said.“I know a lot of people, even women, can find that funny, but I don’t. He just came out with it, he had been talking about someone looking for me ‘because you’re a big cougar’. I nearly fell off the chair. I just don’t find that funny or acceptable. It was a horrible feeling, the worst thing to say to a woman.“On every occasion that he did say something, I was at my desk typing or doing my admin work. I didn’t ask for this, he came to me to insult me.”Askedshe felt the insults were down to vindictiveness or just immaturity, she replied: “I really don’t know what he was thinking. It just beggars belief what was going through his head. All I wanted was to do my job and head home, but I was absolutely dreading it.Ms Murray also thanked her legal team, solicitor Brian Archer and barrister Michael Potter, for their “total support” throughout the entire process.Most ReadCommunity heartbroken after Co Down man Kevin Gregory dies suddenly in UkraineStorm Dudley: Weather warning brought forwardCivil servants set for hybrid working policy in two months‘There’s loads of ways to be a family’: Derry dads make surrogacy historyStephen Nolan explores ‘heart-breaking’ family history in new BBC documentaryTop Videos title: mid and east antrim borough council appoints interim chief to replace anne donaghy amid legal proceedings
story: Council HQ: The Braid in Ballymena. Credit: Arts Fund FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCouncil HQ: The Braid in Ballymena. Credit: Arts FundNiamh CampbellTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailMark Parkinson has been named as interim chief executive of Mid and East Antrim Borough Council.He will officially take over from current acting chief, Philip Thompson, who secured the post in  temporary capacity following the suspension of previous boss, Anne Donaghy.Ms Donaghy has since made a series of explosive claims against the council in a case alleging sexual, religious and political discrimination.Read MoreCouncil’s next chair of taskforce will also be paid £, a dayWhat Mid  East Antrim taskforce has achieved for £K a dayMr Parkinson will officially take on the new role on Monday, February , having recently served as of deputy chief executive at Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council.He has also worked in England, where he was deputy chief at Shepway District Council from  to , and served as deputy chief executive at Exeter City Council, from  to .Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The council said Mr Parkinson’s appointment “follows a comprehensive recruitment process overseen on behalf of the council by the local government staffing commission”.Elected members agreed to his new role at a meeting on Monday evening.Meanwhile, Ms Donaghy’s legal case against her employer is ongoing, as she claims her suspension from work in December was “unlawful”, and has accused an official of spreading “untruthful allegations” that she had a drink problem.Having come from a Catholic background, she also made allegations of discrimination “on the grounds of sex, religious beliefs and political opinion”.The council had said that it does “not comment on staffing matters” and as respondents to the claim, it and any others named will have the right to reply in writing and give their side of the case.Speaking about Mr Parkinson’s new appointment, Mayor William McCaughey, said: “Mid and East Antrim Borough Council has a proud and rich reputation for excellent frontline service delivery and I am confident Mark will build on that and help drive us forward.He brings impressive experience and expertise, and will be a welcome addition to our senior management team at a very busy time.“The past two years have been extremely challenging for our entire community and our businesses across the borough as a result of the pandemic, and as a council, we are fully focused and committed to providing all the support, guidance and leadership required to pave the way for a strong recovery and future prosperity in Mid and East Antrim.“I want to thank our director Philip Thompson for his hard work and dedication as acting chief executive in recent months, and I commend the senior management team and all our staff throughout the organisation for their continued delivery of superb services to all our residents.”Related topicsMid and East Antrim Borough CouncilMore On Mid and East Antrim Borough CouncilCouncils warned over possible #strike action# with bin collections among services that could be title: northern ireland job market covid recovery continues as payroll employees reaches highest level
story: The Covid recovery is continuing. Photo: Pacemaker Press FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe Covid recovery is continuing. Photo: Pacemaker PressEimear McGovernTwitterEmailFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailJob market recovery is continuing in Northern Ireland as the number of payrolled employees is now higher than pre-Covid for the eighth consecutive month, according to new data.Payrolls are now risen by % year-on-year and the number of employees being paid through HMRC here in January is now , - the highest on record.However, the recovery from the impact of Covid is not yet complete, with total employmentand hours worked yet toto pre-Covid levels.Compared to the pre-pandemic levels in October-December , the total number of hours worked in October-December  was % below, whilst the employment rate was .% below.Both the unemployment and economic inactivity rates remain above the pre-pandemic position .In January , the seasonally adjusted number of people on the claimant count was , , a decrease of from the previous month’s revised figure. The January claimant count is % below the recent peak in May , and % higher than the pre-pandemic count in March .And the economic inactivity rate increased over the quarterand over the yearto .%. Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Earnings from the HMRC PAYE indicated that NI employees had a median monthly pay of £, in January , an increase of £over the month and an increase of £over the year.The labour market statistics were published on Tuesday by the Northern Ireland Statistics  Research Agency.Meanwhile, the proportion of people aged  to  in work or the employment rate increased by . percentage points over both the quarter and the year to .%. Neither the quarterly nor annual changes were statistically signicant.The economic inactivity rateincreased over the quarterand over the yearto .%.The latest HMRC payroll data showed that employee numbers were .% above those recorded in March  pre-COVID. All sectors with the exception of finance and insurance reported an increase over the year.The accommodation and food sector reported the largest percentage increase over the year , where employees in this sector are just abovethose recorded pre-pandemic.Most ReadCommunity heartbroken after Co Down man Kevin Gregory dies suddenly in UkraineStorm Dudley: Weather warning brought forwardCivil servants
