title: ‘Hinch lose out in league clash
story: BALLYNAHINCH lost out to a strong PSNI side in their latest Ulster Intermediate League encorenter.A PSNI pass back opened the first quarter and immediately they looked to keep possession.lsquoHinch were able to apply pressure early on to PSNI with passes from the Ashley Brown up to Jason Campbell in midfield, who playing the ball quickly to Adam Dodds in attack.However, this attack was brought to an abrupt end by the willing PSNI defence.lsquoHinch also displayed some noteworthy defence, with Andrew Mulholland and Scott Leetch thwarted PSNI attacks into their circle.With both teams keeping the pressure on, PSNI were able to get on the scoresheet first with a cross goal deflection at the back post.Ballynahinch were forced back further which produced great saves from lsquokeeper Aaron Donnell and super defending by the four of Leslie Harrison, Ashley Brown, Andrew Mulholland and Scott Leetch.lsquoHinch dispossessed the PSNI opposition early in the second quarter with Josh Higginson and Harry Bell working the ball well up the left side to win a short corner.The hosts came close but PSNI managed to clear the ball off the line for a long corner. Hugo Melville and Kyle Patterson worked well up the right side before crossing the ball across the circle only to intercepted by PSNI.Both teams were able to win short corners throughout the quarter but neither were able to convert their chances.lsquoHinch were quick to attack and go looking for the elusive goal as the third quarter commenced, with Adam Dodds sending alovely cross circle ball to Ross Connolly, who narrowly missed the goal with at the back post.Craig Harkness and Zack Patterson kept PSNI at bay on both wings with super tackles although Ballynahinch knew they had to go for it and pressed higher up the pitch leaving space at the back.lsquoHinch lsquokeeper Aaron Donnell was able to deny the opposition by making a one on one tackle before clearing the ball out of his circle.However, PSNIrsquos counterattacks continued and they were able to win a penalty stroke after the ball found a lsquoHinch foot on the goal line. The visitors made no mistake and converted the chance.With both teams knowing the result was not secured yet they were going for every ball and every pass. Ballynahinchrsquos Jason Campbell and Ashley Brown passed the ball back and fourth to make progress up the pitch.lsquoHinch were able to apply most of the pressure on to PSNI, who were playing the majority of the final quarter in their own half.PSNI were able to take advantage of this and were able to convert for their third of the day.Harry Bell displayed some wonderful skills keeping the ball while under pressure from the opposition soon after.However, this didnrsquot stop PSNI, who were able to add their fourth and final goal of the day after a super run down the right hand side and along the base line was followed by the ball deflecting over the lsquoHinch keeper to be tapped in at the back post..prettyPhoto

title: Archbishop recalls life and faith of St Patrick during celebration mass
story: SAUL once more began a place of religious pilgrimage when the Papal Nuncio to Ireland visited the area last Wednesday.His Excellency Archbishop Jude Thaddeus Okolo visited St Patrickrsquos Church on the Feast of Candlemas mdash or the the Feast of the Purication of the Blessed Virgin Mary mdash as part of a St Patrickrsquos Novena across Ireland.The visit was part of a new initiative for the renewal of faith through devotion to an all-island novena which follows in the steps of St Patrick.Archbishop Eamon Martin launched the nine-week novena taking place in churches which have links to St Patrick, which started in Armagh Cathedral last month.The Papal Nuncio was welcomed to Saul by the parish priest, Fr Paul Alexander, along with parishioners, including schoolchildren, who gathered in the church close to where Irelandrsquos patron saint began his mission.The celebration of faith included Mass, Adoration and the Rosary.Two first class relics of St Patrick were also displayed for public veneration ndash the relic of his jawbone from thetreasury of the Church in Down and Connor diocese and also a piece of bone which came to Ireland from Rome in .St Patrickrsquos altar stone is also in the beautul church which is also famous for its stained glass windows telling the story of St Patrickrsquos arrival in Saul.In his homily, Fr Paul Alexander said: ldquoSt Patrickrsquos first church in Ireland was here in Saul and from here the faith spread.ldquoSt Patrick brought the light of Christ to Ireland, the same light we read about in the Gospel today on this feast day of the Presentation, the feast of light. We have to follow the example of St Patrick and bring the light to recallsothers.ldquoWe have to start again, bringing the light of Christ into our hearts, our families and into our homes. We all know these are days of darkness, we have been living through them, days of fear and anxiety. We need the joy of the gospel, the joy of Christ, joy brought to Ireland by St Patrick.Fr Alexander continued: ldquoEach of us has to ask ourselves, what am I going to do to bring the light of faith to others  Generations of our ancestors kept the faith alive. What are you going to do to keep the faith alive  Let us revive our faith and go forward with St Patrick.Archbishop Jude Thaddeus told the congregation that St Patrick was not sent by to Ireland ldquoby God by chance.ldquoHis mission in Ireland was a deliberate intention of God, he continued. ldquoWe can read this in St Patrickrsquos writings and from the example he left behind. When St Patrick wanted to come back to Ireland, there was a lot of opposition. In his time, there were many missionaries, including bishops and priests. We have hardly heard of many of these, but we all know about St Patrick. This is very striking. Why is it so ldquoSt Patrick did not speak much, he didnrsquot write much. Today there are too many words ndash words, words, words ndash written words, spoken words, words on the internet, words on the microphone, words on the streets and the market places. There are too many words, just one word is important ndash the Word of God. If we could just listen to even a single Word of God.Referring to the Gospel readings for the feast of Candlemas, the Papal Nuncio added: ldquoOur Lady did not say anything at the Presentation of Our Lord, she kept everything in her heart. In the entire Gospel. St Joseph speaks only two words. Sometimes we speak too many words and we lose orientation and get confused. Only one word is important ndash the Word of God ndash we should listen to the Word of God. St Patrick listened to the Word of God.Speaking afterwards of his visit, Archbishop Okolo said: ldquoIt was indeed nice and uplting, praying together on that holy ground, on which St Patrick trod.Next week, the All Ireland Novena journeys to Slane where St Patrick lit the Paschal fire.The Novena can be watched online at pm via the parish webcam..prettyPhoto

title: Children on stage for The Wizard of Oz show
story: THE abundance of musical and dramatic talent at the Patrician Youth Centre in Downpatrick is back on show for the first time in almost two years.A young and enthusiastic cast presented the pantomime, The Wizard of Oz, last week.Performing Arts and live productions at the Patrician paused in March  with the onset of Covid- and ensuing pandemic.Determined to get going again, staff and members worked on Tom Whalleyrsquos new pantomime production of the very popular musical The Wizard of Oz.Despite many ongoing Covid disruptions were delighted to have a performance which was live streamed last week.Unfortunately, in the lead-up to the event some of the principal cast members were Covid isolating.On the day before the performance leading lady Shona Gardiner, who was to play Dorothy, tested positive.In true showbiz tradition, the show had to go on and a telephone call from a former Patrician member saved the day.Mairead OrsquoHare, who played Dorothy in the Patricianrsquos  production of the Wizard of Oz, volunteered to stand in to read the role and sing the ever-popular songs. Mairead ed and performed like she never had been away.Senior youth worker Yvonne Maguire congratulated everyone connected with the production mdash the cast members, production team, friends of Patrician, parents, and families for supporting members, children and young people.She extended a sincere thank you to Mairead for standing in at the last minute and also paid tribute to Shona, who had worked so hard in preparing for the performance and regrettably did not get the opportunity to star.A recording of Shona singing will be available on Facebook.The principal cast members were: Mairead OrsquoHare , Aaron Mullan , Aedan OrsquoHare , Annie May OrsquoHare , Eamon OrsquoHare , Eva Bailie , Tyler Fung , Zoe Gaines .Chorus, dancers, monkeys, trees and crows: Caitie Cunlfe, Caragh Moore, Conal McDowell, Ella Grace Cunlfe, Emily Douglas, Georgia Savage, Jack McDonald, Katie Fegan, Kayleigh Rogers, Lilly Boyd, Maria Rooney, Megan Megahey, Molly Boyd, Molly Madine, Oisin OrsquoHare, Poppy Baggley, Poppy Woodall.Patrician Youth Centre would also like to thank the following staff team and friends for making the production possible: Caitriona Smyth, Anthony Frew, Bridin Wells, Eamonn Hanlon, Charlie Hanlon, David McBennett, Melissa Poland, Paddy Watters, Mark Hassett, Anna Murray and Teresa Sweeney.Thanks are also extended other team members and the centre trainee leader membership who supported the event..prettyPhoto

title: Drive for better sea swimming facilities
story: A SERIES of measures to improve the safety of sea swimmers in Newcastle have been suggested to Newry, Mourne and Down Council.The local authority has been asked to address the needs of the increasing numbers who enjoy swimming at the resortrsquos harbour.Council officials met recently with Mournes councillor Laura Devlin who is working to secure improved access to the water and the needs of those who enjoy cold water swimming.Cllr Devlin said while sea swimming has always been popular in the resort, there is an increasing number of people taking to the water as a result of Covid which prompted many people across the district to be more active.She said Newcastlersquos Harbour Heritage Association is bringing many people who use services at the harbour together to provide them with a ldquounied voice with the group including representatives of the sea swimming community.ldquoCold water therapy is now an established activity and the coronavirus pandemic will unfortunately have a lasting impact on mental health, continued Cllr Devlin.ldquoThis type of therapy is seen as a successful line of defence and even treatment for many, notwithstanding the superb physical benefits and enjoyment that cold water swimming brings.Cllr Devlin says there are many activities at Newcastle harbour which can sometimes lead to a congested slipway, explaining that there are ldquosignicant safety concerns when swimmers, boats and jet-skis are in the water at once.The local councillor, who met recently with council officials and was joined by local sea swimmer Fiona Davey, has also highlighted parking problems at the harbour which she said are ldquocontinuing to deteriorate.She continued: ldquoI have also consulted with The Harbour Heritage Association and we agreed a list of issues that need to be addressed which the local authority which is considering improvements to the water access point on the harbour side of the Rock Pool or at the Back Shore.ldquoAn extension of the ramp leading to the water is also required to allow for disability access, while a handrail to assist people entering and exiting the water as well as hooks for clothes and storage, and a seating area for changing is also required.Council officials have also been asked to provide buoys near the pier to section off the area for those jumping into the water and sea swimming in general.Cllr Devlin also highlighted the need for height markers on the pier wall in order that those who jump into the water will know the depth, explaining the water depth can be an issue during the summer months.Council officials have also been asked to provide distance markers, so swimmers know how far out they are.Cllr Devlin added: ldquoThis is a flavour of our asks and really is just a starting point. I donrsquot see any of the issues that have been highlighted as costing a signicant amount. If they can be implemented, they would make a tangible dference to harbour users. I hope that progress can be made soon for the good of all harbour users.Thanking Cllr Devlin for her work to improve safety for sea swimmers at the harbour, South Down MLA Colin McGrath said he looked forward to ldquomuch-needed changes in Newcastle.He also believes that the series of measures outlined for the harbour could be used as a template by the local authority for open water swimming and cold water therapy across the district.Mr McGrath added: ldquoWe are fortunate to be surrounded by such beautul coastline which has many locations for accessing the water, but itrsquos vital that we make the activity as safe as possible in a select number of locations that ensure an equitable offering across the council area..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C  February 12th%2C 1992
story: ARDGLASS ndash The fishing fleet in Ardglass is facing a potential crisis following a slump in the crucially-important prawn market.Demand for prawns has ped dramatically because of the recession, resulting in depressed prices and trawler men struggling to meet running costs.Yesterday, fishermenrsquos leader Dick James said: ldquoWe are not yet in a crisis, but one is fast developing.Mr James, who is chief executive of the Northern Ireland Fish Producersrsquo Organisation, has called on the Government to introduce a decommissioning scheme which would enable trawler owners to leave the industry.ldquoA decommissioning scheme would go a long way towards solving the problem. At present, we have too many boasts chasing too few fish, he remarked.Ironically, the situation has been partly caused by the fishermen catching too many prawns.Last monthrsquos good weather resulted in better-then-expected landing which further depressed the already-weakened market ndash prawn are currently selling at less than pound a stone, compared to pound a stone a year ago.However, the general recession in the economy has been the main stumbling block. As demand continues to drop, processors are keeping stocks in cold storage and are not in a position to buy additional supplies at the quayside.ldquoWe had good prices until last April. Then the market slumped and prices drop. Unfortunately, fishermanrsquos costs havenrsquot come down accordingly, Mr James said.Mr James said depression in other sectors of the industry has heightened the problem.He also believes the decommission scheme has the support of most trawler owners in Ardglass.ldquoWe are talking about the survival of the fleet as a whole. Decommissioning would help owners who are otherwise unable to get out of the industry.ldquoAnd because most of the boats are undermanned, it would to not lead to large scale redundancies among crewmen, he added.CROSSGAR ndash A Crossgar man who is renowned for his excellent time-keeping was honoured last week.Mr James McCormick, who has been winding the clock on the old Kilmore Parish Church Hall for over  years, has decided to hang up his key and retire from his conscientious job.James took over the job when the clock was repaired in  and has continued his labour of love ever since.Now the hall has been sold to the Ulster Wildle Trust for its new headquarters building, James has decided tocall it a day and has retired from his winding duties.In recognition of his timeless work over the years the development officer of the Wildle Trust, Mr Niall Timmins, presented Mr McCormick with a window box of herbs to remind him of his former winding le.STRANGFORD ndash The creation of a single committee to oversee the management of Strangford Lough has been widely welcomed.The Ulster Unionist MP for Strangford, Mr John Taylor, said the announcement represents a ldquomajor U-turn by the Government, while the Strangford Lough Nature Conservation Association described it as a ldquoserious attempt to ensure the future of the lough.The new committee is to be launched in the spring and will have a membership of around  drawn from special interest groups, such as agriculture, fishing, conservation and recreation.Member will also be appointed from nominations put forward by Down District and Ards Borough Councils, the National Trust and the Council for Nature Conservation and the Countryside.The announcement marks something of a turn-around by the Environment Minister, Mr Richard Needham, who less than six months ago proposed a two-tier management structure for the lough.The proposal was widely criticised by groups who argued that such a structure would be unwieldy and would prevent local people from having a proper influence over decision making.By scrapping that approach, Mr Needham appears to have bowed to local pressure. The Minister says the new initiative has been produced ldquofollowing extensive consultation with organisations and iniduals concerned with the future of Strangford Lough.SAINTFIELD ndash Work is to start next week leading to the provision of new traffic lights in Saintfield.The townrsquos Ulster Unionist councillor, Mr William Biggerstaff, said yesterday that preliminary work will begin on Monday for the provision of the lights at the main crossroads in the town.ldquoI welcome this commitment. At long last we are to get these light, he said.After meeting Roads Service officials, Mr Biggerstaff also announced progress on a number of other projects in the Saintfield area.He said the provision of a footpath along Middle Road is to go forward to the Departmentrsquos forward planning section, as well similar provision on the Ballynahinch Road, Saintfield, as far as Ballymaconnell Road.Mr Biggerstaff said he had also been assured that a footpath extension from Lislane Park to the new build on the Listooder Road, taking in the primary school area will ldquodefinitely happen this year.The Ulster Unionist councillor has also asked officials to carry out a study into a serious flooding problem during periods of heavy rain at Carsonstown Road Killybawn Road.NEWCASTLE ndash Down councillor, Mr John Ritchie, has claimed that the Eastern Health Board consultation process is the ldquokiss of death for Mourne House.In a strong address to the Eastern Health Council attacking the closer plan for Mourne House, Mr Ritchie said that in his experience consultation rarely results in a change to such a proposal.Mr Ritchie claimed the unit of management has looked at the Mourne House scenario from a narrow perspective and he voiced concern about the future of the elderly people in the outlying parts of the community.It was the local councillor who asked for the Mourne House issue to be put on the Council agenda for Thursdayrsquos meeting and he dominated the  minute discussion.During his address Mr Ritchie suggested the implementation of a two-year programme to deal with the renovations and the building could then be used as a base for a community care programme.Mr Ritchie explained that Mourne House first came to light in the dying days of the last Eastern Health Board when the policy and planning committee considered a plan for the Down and Lisburn Unit of Management.The proposal included reducing the number of beds to  and developing Mourne House as a base for a community care package with respite care, a  place day centre, and meals on wheels.Mr Ritchie said there were a whole range of suggestions which the Board felt made a ldquovery attraction option.CLOUGH ndash The Presbyterian congregation in Clough held a thanksgiving service on Sunday to bid farewell to their  year-old church hall which is being replaced.The hall which was built in , is being demolished to make way for a new hall which will be officially opened by the Moderator of the Presbyterian Church, the Rev Rodney Sterritt, in April.The services was conducted by the Rev Robert Craig, church minister, who researched the origins and construction of the hall at the turn of the century.The hymn, psalm and ure reading were the same as those used at the opening service.The ious organisations which used the hall over the years were remembered, including the Scouts and Guides, Boysrsquo and Girlsrsquo Brigades, the Girlsrsquo auxiliary, and the badminton, bowls and table tennis clubs.The congregation also remembered the many services and church socials which were held in the hall.In his address, Mr Craig pointed to the strong links between the current congregation and that of a bygone age.He said many of the original families still reside in the Clough area and belong to the congregation.Mr Craig said the congregation is still industrious and is currently busy erecting and paying for the new hall. He also pointed to the faith which has united the generations..prettyPhoto

title: Head teachers take part in two day leadership event
story: HEAD teachers from post-primary schools across the South Eastern area took part in a two-day conference last week in Newcastle.The event at the Burrendale Hotel focused on leadership, building resilience, promoting health and well-being amongst staff and students, child protection issues and supporting children and young people to get the best educational start in le.A core theme of the conference was on ldquorestarting, rebuilding and adapting the education system coming out of a global pandemic.Mr Paul Marks, principal of The High School Ballynahinch and current chairman of the South Eastern Secondary Heads Association, described the conference as a ldquoreally important opportunity for school leaders to reflect on the challenges and key opportunities of the past two years.ldquoIt is so important that principals meet to discuss our recovery out of the Covid- pandemic and how we can continue to best support all of our pupils to realise their full potential, he said.Education Authority chief executive Sara Long mdash who opened the conference mdash paid tribute to the leadership and tireless efforts of all school principals and staff throughout the pandemic.She thanked them for their ldquooutstanding commitment, dedication and resilience in the face of the most dficult of circumstances.She said children and young people, staff and school communities remained ldquosteadfastly at the heart of everything schools do.ldquoYou transitioned seamlessly to remote and blended learning, prepared for a number of school restarts, navigated through ever-changing public health advice and policies and managed very high volumes of Covid- cases in your schools, said the chief executive.ldquoYou managed this against the back of signicant staffing shortages and ensured that all young people received the appropriate grade at GSCE and A-Level through rigorous assessment, due diligence and hard work by you and your teaching staff.Ms Long also acknowledged how dficult the journey had been and the impact that all this had on head teachers should not be ignored.ldquoThat is why I want to stress my commitment in continuing to look at how we can best support school leaders, build strong partnerships and networks and to promote and champion health and wellbeing, she added..prettyPhoto

title: Kilmore move to second place in title race for Division 1A trophy
story: KILMORE Rec established themselves as serious title contenders after they defeated current table toppers Comber Rec at a wet and windy Robert Adams Park on Saturday.Despite missing a first half penalty, The Blues dusted themselves down and found the crucial goal through their captain, Niall McCarthy, which was enough to separate the sides in what was a very physical encounter between the two rivals.It was the home side who kicked off the affair and immediately it was clear to both sets of supporters that they were in for an action packed  minutes of football.Comber striker Matthew Tumilson stung the hands of Kilmore lsquokeeper Christopher Turley early on before Gary Kennedy tried his luck from range for the hosts.Although the worsening conditions made the pitch notably heavy, the quality of football on display didnrsquot decline to the credit of both outfits.In fact, the heavy and cut up grass resulted in a cuter range of passing with the minutes on the training pitch preparing for such scenarios put into full effect.However, Kilmore soon had other worries when defender Kennedy was forced off just  minutes into play as a result of an injury. Fortunately for The Blues they had an able replacement in Christopher Magee.This early unsettlement, along with the travelling support, spurred the away side on and soon the league leaders were showing why they are just that.Gareth Keenan was denied a golden opportunity courtesy of a point blank save from Turley as Comber continued to apply pressure in the early stages. Kilmore responded well to this and remained calm on the ball.Following some quick passing from Matthew Stewart to team-mate Anton McGrattan, the Kilmore number ten played in strike partner Joe McKinney, who was adjudged to have been fouled in the danger area and won a penalty kick.Kilmorersquos McGrattan stepped up but his effort was fantastically saved by the outstretching Andrew Topping, who pushed the ball around the post and out for a corner to the frustration of the home fans.The resultant corner was headed over the Comber crossbar by Kilmore defender Jack Larkin as the away side relished in escaping potential punishment.The visitors went back in search of the opening goals immediately after, with Keenan again seeing his efforts thwarted by the Kilmore custodian.The game quickly developed into an end to end contest with chances coming thick and fast at both ends.Kilmorersquos McKinney saw his headed effort go wide with the goal seemingly gaping before his left footed effort blazed over the bar after he was neatly played through by McGrattan.Comberrsquos Brandon Nelson delivered an inviting corner to the head of team-mate Stuart Moore, although he failed to make the most of his chance.Despite the weather, things began heating up on the pitch with numerous crunching tackles on display.Kilmore captain, Niall McCarthy, escaped with just a warning following his high challenge on Comber winger Nelson although the visiting sidersquos Moore wasnrsquot as lucky after he was awarded a yellow for clattering substitute Magee.A new face was on show within the Kilmore ranks in the form of midfielder Barry Walsh. The former Killyleagh YC player impressed throughout his debut and controlled the middle of the park at ious stages throughout the game.With both the tempo and tensions high, the whistle sounded a full two minutes early to signal half-time.Comber kicked off after the interval but it was the hosts who would be awarded the first big chance of the half.Following a piercing run into the opposing defence, Kilmorersquos McKinney was brought down awarding team-mate McGrattan to test lsquokeeper Topping from  yards with the resultant free-kick.However, the Comber custodian wasnrsquot required to spring into action as the ball whisked past the wrong side of the upright.The visitors seemed to be pressed further back into their half and attempted to respond quickly.Dylan Wilson smartly dispatched of the ball on a quick counter-attack to team-mate and captain, Simon Hanna, although the number eight was halted in his tracks unfairly by Magee.For this, the Kilmore defender was the latest name to enter the refereersquos books. The home side had the advantage of the wind and decided to use this repeatedly through long ranged passes in hopes of manufacturing an attack.McKinney came close on a few occasions as he engaged in multiple footraces with Comberrsquos Reece Whittle, although often the home striker would stray onto the bounds of offside.Kilmore hit a purple patch in the opening quarter of the second half, with Comberrsquos first chance of the restart coming on the hour mark.Nelson was left unmarked at the back post after a ball was lofted into his path from skipper Hanna. However, he shanked his left-footed effort and allowed his Kilmore counterparts to remain unscathed.Despite this miss, Nelsonrsquos effort served as a reminder to the opposition that Comber was very much still a threat on the counter.The Kilmore support were up in arms minutes later when they thought a Comber hand was used to prevent a McGrattan strike from hitting its target, although these appeals were quickly shut down.Comber substitute, Ciaran Gillan, picked up a yellow card in his attempts to clear the ball from his half ndash much to the disagreement of his sidersquos management team.The visitors would be soon ruing more than a yellow card as the resultant free-kick proved costly on the  minute mark.A delicately placed McGrattan delivery floated into the path of captain McCarthy for the Kilmore skipper to head with conviction past Topping and finally open the scoring.Anton McGrattan picked up a rather needless yellow soon after for thumping the ball away amongst the celebrations as the atmosphere inside the park reached fever pitch.Comber defender Bradley Porter received a yellow card minutes later for his tackle on McKinney before the Kilmore striker suffered the same fate after he ended up on the ground in what the referee deemed as simulation.The trend of yellow cards continued with Comber captain Hanna, who landed his name in the book for exchanging some ill-advised words with the official ten minutes from full-time.As expected, the final minutes of the contest were a nervous affair for the home side, who werenrsquot committing as many bodies forward in hopes of securing a shutout.Naturally, this invited pressure from Comber, who desperately sought to spoil the Kilmore party.lsquoKeeper Turley kept his concentration for the full duration of the match and thwarted the last two efforts from Comber, with Wilson coming close before his team-mate Tumilson was denied dramatically in injury time.This signied the last piece of action as the referee brought his whistle to his lips to the relief of the Kilmore support.Following the conclusion goal scorer and man of the match, Niall McCarthy, gave his thoughts on his sidersquos impressive victory.ldquoIt was a battle, the pitch was very heavy and I think it just came down to who wanted it more, he said.ldquoWe knew with Comber coming down here that they are a very physical, very fit team, who are well-drilled.ldquoHowever, we firmly believe in our camp that we are the best team in the league. We work hard every Tuesday and Thursday night and itrsquos a credit to our manager, Michael Carvill, for the shape hersquos pulled us in to.Kilmore: C Turley, J McCarthy, M Stewart, J Larkin, G Kennedy, B Walsh, J Smyth, N McCarthy , J McKinney, A McGrattan, E McGrattan.Subs: C Magee, M Monan, M Carvill.Yellow cards: C Magee, A McGrattan, J McKinney.Comber: A Topping, M Gibson, L Walker, B Porter, R Whittle, S Moore, B Nelson, S Hanna , D Wilson, M Tumilson, G Keenan.Subs: S Fleck, C Gillan, K Gaw.Yellow cards: S Moore, C Gillan, B Porter, S Hanna..prettyPhoto

title: Knockevin in £75k funding initiative
story: KNOCKEVIN Special Schoolrsquos Parent Staff Association has unveiled details of an ambitious pound, fundraising initiative.The school has bases in Downpatrick, Dundrum and Castlewellan, with the parent and staff group hoping that the ldquoenchantment project will raise vital funds to purchase essential outdoor play and learning equipment.In addition, some of the pound, will be used to meet school bus running costs and other essential items at Knockevinrsquos three bases.Announcing details of the new fundraising initiative, the parent and staff group said pupils are in need of ious items to help combat social deprivation as a result of the ongoing pandemic.ldquoOur children may not always have the same opportunity for social inclusion as those in mainstream education, but to be able to provide them with an outdoor space they can safely and comfortably enjoy together which is fully accessible and tailored to all their needs would be a dream come true, said a spokesperson for the group.ldquoOur children and young adults are most deserving of this. and, as with all specialist equipment, a large price tag is included and we aim to hold as many fundraising activities and events as possible to ensure that we reach our goal.As Covid restrictions continue to ease, the highly acclaimed special school will be able to hold its th anniversary at Newcastlersquos Burrendale Hotel on September , with entertainment provided by the Booze Bros and Finbarr Keaveney the compere for the evening.ldquoWe are looking forward to getting together again to celebrate all that has been achieved in the past  years. Everyone is welcome to join us and more details will follow on how to purchase tickets on our Facebook page, the spokesperson continued.ldquoWe have essentially been fundraising since September and received our first donation from the Blaney family. The money was raised at the Oisin Blaney Memorial hurling blitz last August and we also held a street collection in Castlewellan before Christmas, with the generosity of the local community amazing.The spokesperson said Knockevin enjoyed the support of local businesses and the community, but more support was essential to help it raise the pound, required for the project.The parent and staff group, which also includes volunteers, was founded in  to raise funds for all three of the Knockevin school sites.And while fundraising has been hampered by the ongoing pandemic, the group is hoping that many businesses and the community will weigh in with support for the new fundraising initiative.Progress reports on the drive to secure the money required to create an enchanted space for children and young adults will be posted on the grouprsquos Facebook page..prettyPhoto

title: Local clubs compete in latest outing at Delamont
story: THE McGrady Financial Services junior cross country series continued on Sunday with race two at Delamont Country Park.The weather lived up to the unsettled forecast with high winds and squally showers but there was occasional respite when the skies turned blue and glacial sunshine broke through.In the days prior there was debate as to whether it would be too inclement for the event to take place but there was a real determination to proceed as racing has been in short supply due to the pandemic.East Down AC was the host club for this one and so a stalwart band consisting of EDAC junior coaches and committee, ably assisted by parent volunteers, toughed it out to deliver a full program of events.Setting the course up posed problems as the ground was soft and while mud is part and parcel of cross country, there were areas that were not runnable. However, by pm the taped route was ready, the registration was complete and the nervous but excited youngsters were warming up in anticipation.Primary Four and under lined up, first the boys and then the girls. With vests down to their knees and a few anxious glances to parents, it seemed that they were almost too young for such a task but once the whistle blew they set off like rockets round the m circuit.Harry McVeigh, for Newcastle AC, was the clear winner in the boysrsquo race and Aoe Maguireheld a five second lead to win the girlsrsquo race.Primary Five saw the girls and boys combined in the one race and the winners were John McElroyand Emily Kerr . The  metres didnrsquot seem a bother to either of these young athletes.Ryan Thorntonwent off hard for the P win and Saorlaith McAleenanwas the epitome of focus as she headed to the line to come first in the P girls.With  entrants and the distance now one kilometre, it was a challenging race.The P looked an experienced bunch as they gathered at the start.Many have been racing each other in the Flahavanrsquos XC Series for schools so there were scores to be settled. Maisie McVeighwas taking no chances and after a short tussle, she shrugged off the rest of the field and ran solo to take the P girlsrsquo victory.Fiachna McAleenanalso showed his mettle leading home the P boys. This was raced over m.It was great to see the support for the younger ones, not just from parents but from older siblings and club mates, who ran along side each race yelling at the younger ones to encourage them to work hard right to the finish line.On more than one occasion there were groups breaching the line as an inseparable unit and joint times had to be awarded. This was exciting for spectators and a learning experience for the runners.In time they will develop the ability to pace over the course to keep their position but leave a little in the tank for a sprint finishrequired.The series is about participation as well as competition and all runners get a point for their club provided they finish the race.This helps to engender club spirit and creates a charged atmosphere.The post primary runners were well warmed up from their cheerleading efforts on the sideline so they were primed for racing when it was eventually their turn.In Years Eight, Nine and Ten, the girls outnumbered the boys in each category but by Year  plus, it was the reverse.Still, it was good to see healthy numbers out to take part overall in the post primary end of things. The distance for year eight was m and Erin Easton , who won the girlsrsquo race by eight seconds, looked controlled throughout. Aaron OrsquoBoylehad an exciting sprint to the line to snatch glory in Year Eight boys.Emma Stewartcovered the m Year Nine girlsrsquo race at great speed to place first girl and Alex Robinson seemed to revel in the extra running as the gap between him and the second runner stretched out as the race proceeded.Year Ten boys and girls ran together as there were  when combined.The m race allowed spectators to get multiple glimpses as the they looped round the field.Aaron Lennonwon his race comfortably and Edana Butterfieldhad a similar outcome in the girlsrsquo category.The finale was Year  and up. This had a mix of gender as well as year groups. The athletes seemed to have doubled in height compared to the first race of the day and they looked powerful and committed as they loped past with long strides.The two kilometre race was a display of pacing and control with the speed picking up in the last lap.Ollie Robinsonmade sure he held his lead to the line and Amy McCartanran strongly to come first in the girlsrsquo section.Racing completed there was a flurry to clear up before the next shower and many hands made light work.Thanks are due to all the volunteers ndash both those who are involved on the day and those who do the admin behind the scenes. The commitment of the young runnersis highly commendable and the continued backing of McGrady Financial Services is much appreciated.These young folk are the future of our clubs and the sport in general and all those who are facilitating this, know that it is time well spent.The next race is in Tollymore Forest Park on March . See you all there..prettyPhoto

title: Masked men leave elderly  couple shaken after raid
story: AN elderly Castlewellan couple are recovering from shock after four masked men broke into their home last Friday evening.A man in his seventies and a woman in her sixties were not physically injured in the frightening incident but were left shaken by their ordeal.It is understood the men broke in by the front door as the couple were watching television at their home in the St Malachyrsquos Drive area.A police spokesman said: ldquoShortly after pm, it was reported that four masked men entered the property and searched it, before making off empty-handed.ldquoOne of the men was described as being approximately  ft in height, and well built.ldquoThe occupants of the house, a man in his s and a woman in her s, were both inside at the time of the incident.ldquoOur enquiries are ongoing, and we would appeal to anyone with any information, or who may have been in the area at the time and witnessed any suspicious activity, to contact us on , quoting reference number  of   .Sinn Fein councillor Roisin Howell condemned the burglary and called for anyone in the area at the time who may have witnessed something to get in touch with the police.ldquoThe one place that people can expect to feel safe is in their home and when that is threatened it really is too much, she said.ldquoThe couple were understandably very shaken at what happened, but they were not hurt and want to put this behind them.ldquoI hope that this is not the start of other similar break-ins in the area and I would appeal for anyone who saw the men to contact the police.Police can also be contacted anonymously by calling Crimestoppers on    or online at http:crimestoppers-uk.org ..prettyPhoto

title: Matthew salsas his way through  in Dancing With The Stars show
story: LOVE Islander Matthew MacNabb put his muscles to good use by performing some spectacular lts to get through to the next round of Dancing With The Stars.The Downpatrick man and his dance partner Laura Nolan performed a sizzling salsa on Sundayrsquos evening show on RTEacute One.While the Latin dance did not go down too well with the judges, the  year-oldrsquos popularity with viewers meant that he was voted through to next week.Former RTEacute newsreader Aengus MacGrianna and his dance partner Emily Barker became the third couple to leave the show.The fth couple to dance, Matthew and Laura danced to X by the Jonas Brothers featuring Karol G.Matthewrsquos physical prowess and strength impressed but his salsa sway was found to be lacking.Judge Arthur Gourounlian said: ldquoThose lts, I thought I was watching the Olympics. But you need to loosen up. I applaud you for it.Brian Redmond added: ldquoI agree with Arthur. Lts were great. You should have put more lts in, as sometimes it wasnrsquot great in between. You canrsquot always get hip action. Not a salsa without it, while Loraine Barry added: ldquoThe saving grace were the two Ls mdash Laura and lts. You have to have hip action. Those hips are not moving as they should for a salsa. Good effort, but not good enough.Matthew and Laura scored a commendable  from the judges.For Matthew while he was delighted to be voted in, he hoped the score would have been higher.ldquoA couple of the pro dancers told me that itrsquos very rare for pro dancers to be able to do the last lt I did, Matthew told the Recorder. ldquoSo for it get only  was very harsh in my opinion but I think the audience thought that too and so thatrsquos why they voted me in.ldquoI struggled with getting low with the salsa. Latin dancers are typically a lot shorter than ballroom so it is a lot more dficult to get into the ground when yoursquore taller. Saying that I felt pretty good about my dance and the lts were really good so Irsquom happy with that.He continues to be grateful for all the support of viewers back home and around the island for voting for me.ldquoI just want to thank everyone who is voting for me and supporting me on the show. I really appreciate it and I will keep working hard to do my home proud. So thank you again, he said.Matthew, who is a fitness influencer and digital marketing consultant, revealed that he is back to his comfort zone with a ballroom dance on Sunday.ldquoBallroom is definitely my strength. This week is going to be special because I am dedicating my dance to my friend who passed away in July last year in a tragic accident. He had a big impact on my le andI do nothing  during this entire season, I want to make this a special tribute to him, he said.Matthew is still devoting between five to ten hours each day to learning the new dance and performing it live.Hersquos finding the support of now only his partner Laura, but the rest of the dancers and show production team, to be so inspiring.ldquoI think everyone is so supportive and we all appreciate how dficult it is to learn a dance, a new style of dance within four days and execute it in front of the entire nation, admitted Matthew.ldquoEveryone has ying experience dancing and ying abilities but everyone is still doing it and giving their best so I think we all respect each other for it.Dancing with the Stars continues this on Sunday at .pm on RTEacute One..prettyPhoto

title: McCartan’s men lose second league game
story: DOWN senior footballersrsquo miserable start to their Division Two campaign continued when they fell to a defeat on home soil to Galway on Saturday.Despite a better second half showing, James McCartanrsquos men failed to stamp their authority on the game which was ultimately lost within the opening  minutes.Down, who were draped in their black jerseys for this occasion, started brightly and immediately went in search of the opening point.However, Barry OrsquoHaganrsquos first attempt from the left drted wide and Galway retained possession.Some patient build up play and passing followed by the visitors and although Down managed to momentarily manage this pressure, it wouldnrsquot be long until Galway found the back of the net.Shane Walsh received a quick breakaway pass from team-mate Robert Finnerty, before a neat dummy allowed him to play in Paul Conroy to finish low beneath Gary McMahon with just five minutes gone.Down replied through a Barry OrsquoHagan point, although ious misses from both sides would soon follow. Finnerty eventually notched the next score for his Galway outfit, before the goal scorer, Conroy, would kick over from distance ndash albeit with some wind assistance.The hosts seemed to fighting an uphill battle as the wind battered around Pairc Esler in favour of the visiting side, with Conroy once again managing to point from long range.This opened up a five point winning margin with the Mourne men desperately needing scores on the board.However, the weather could not be at fault for all of their shortcomings as they struggled with the impressive Galway forward line.Walsh was once again involved when he surged past the Down defence before setting up team-mate Owen Gallagher for an easy score.Cormac McCartan attempted to get the home side back into the contest with what seemed like an easy kick over from  metres, although the wind made sure the ball hung in the air before ping comfortably into the hands of Galway lsquokeeper Conor Flaherty.Downrsquos Andrew Gilmore did convert his point three minutes later but as per the theme of the match, Galway replied quickly through Tomo Culhane, who took the mark and scored at the other end.Galway introduced the ing Damien Comer to the fray and with his first touch of the ball he also took the mark and made no mistake with his chance to secure another point for the visitors.Walsh was relishing the blustery conditions and was firing from will at all angles, with one such effort sailing over the black spot from around  metres before the half-time whistle.This signied the last score of a half that contained very few positives for McCartanrsquos side.Half-time: Down - Galway -.The Mourne men registered the opening score of the second half, courtesy of a Barry OrsquoHagan free.Two minutes later, home supporters were perhaps left a little surprised when a goal opportunity presented itself but Cormac McCartan opted instead to play it safe and fire over the bar.Nevertheless, Down had scored two points answered and soon OrsquoHagan would ensure a third after he took the mark and converted the chance.OrsquoHagan continued his impressive start to the second half when he kicked over once again following a turnover in possession.It was now Galway who was struggling with the wind, with Kieran Molloy witnessing his straightforward point from  metres halted by the breeze.Passionate ranting from Down manager, James McCartan, saw him pick up a yellow after exchanging words with the fourth official but there was no denying his side at their tails up.A wide mark from Galwayrsquos Paul Kelly encouraged the hosts further but Gallagher eventually notched his sidersquos first point after the interval following twenty minutes of action.Despite all of Downrsquos hard work, the scoreboard still favoured the visitors by five points in what was a sobering reminder of the home outfitrsquos poor first half display.It didnrsquot help the hosts when Comer notched the next score before Walsh followed suit with a trio of converted frees.Galway attempted to inflict further damage at the death as Tony Gill barrelled down on goal, although he was dragged down before he could unleash his shot.Continuing his impressive kicking form from frees, Walsh once again converted to complete his sidersquos scoring.However, it would be Downrsquos Gilmore who would register the final score of the contest with the last kick of the game, as he curled his left-footed effort over the bar in added time.Following the final whistle, Down manager James McCartan reflected on his sidersquos performance.ldquoWe are disappointed, the game was closer than the six point margin but we lost it in the first half, he said.ldquoWe let Galway play and we werenrsquot putting bodies on the line. I challenged the guys at half-time and there was a big improvement in the first twenty minutes of the second half.ldquoGalway hit us on the break and they went and got a couple of late scores to put a bit of gloss on it. He added: ldquoIrsquom pleased with the second half performance but certainly not with the first.Looking forward to his sidersquos next match, where they face a tough battle away to Meath, the Down boss said: ldquoWersquoll try to get more men back on the field and we will train hard over the next week to try and improve.ldquoYou canrsquot just sit off for  minutes and expect to still be in games.Down: G McMahon, P Fegan, F McElroy, B McArdle R McCormack, N McParland, D OrsquoHagan A Doherty, O Murdock C Mooney, L Kerr, C McCartanB OrsquoHagan , K McKernan, A Gilmore .Subs: C Poland for D OrsquoHagan, P Havern for K McKernan, J McCartan for C Mooney, C Francis for R McCormick, T Close for N McParland.Yellow Card: J McCartanGalway: C Flaherty K Molloy, S Kelly , S McGrath D McHugh, J Daly, C McDaid P Kelly, M Tierney O Gallagher , R Finnerty , F OrsquoLaoi S Walsh , P Conroy , T Culhane .Subs: D Comerfor R Finnerty, P Kelly for F OrsquoLaoi, T Gill for C McDaid, C Sweeney for T Culhane, D Conneely for P Kelly..prettyPhoto

title: Ministerial approval for  ambitious park proposal
story: EXCITEMENT is building around the multi-million pound revamp of the stunningly picturesque Castlewellan Forest Park.Work is already underway on an ambitious scheme which will focus on a number of key areas as part of the major investment programme aimed at restoring the sprawling forest parkrsquos key heritage features to help maximise its tourism potential.The Heritage Lottery Fund has provided almost pound.m in assistance with the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairsand the EU weighing in with pound,.Construction work is well underway at the Bothy Yard in the forest park with other planned work including new landscape and drainage within The Grange courtyard, a new pedestrian path from the entrance gates to the main car park an a new vehicular road off Castle Avenue to the existing car park.There will also be a new traffic control barrier at Castle Avenue and caravan spaces will be relocated with the feature entrance gates at the Castle Avenue entrance restored, alongside the restoration of The Grange courtyard buildings and the reconstruction of a derelict building block.Funding from the government department and Newry, Mourne and Down Council is financing the restoration of the iconic th century greenhouse, reconstruction of the propagation house and cold frames. In addition, one of a number of outbuildings will be converted to an office and volunteer space.Elsewhere, visitor facilities will be created in the Stove Conservatory including an interpretation centre, with a  lt installed to provide access to the terrance for people with reduced mobility.The local council has assumed the development and management of recreation within the park from DAERA under a lease from the Forest Service until  with the lease involving the management of the Bothy Yard walled garden, rhododendron wood and gardenerrsquos house.In addition, the council will assume the management of the wider core recreational area including the main caravan and camping facilities from April , with bookings for the caravan and camping site due to open three days later.The Touring In the Trees facility will continue to be operated by the Forest Service until December , after which the site will transfer to the local authority with the Forest Service continuing to manage the woodland.Council officials have described the Bothy Yard as an ldquointegral part in the restoration of the gardens, as the glasshouses and cold frames will enable the local authority gardening team to propagate and grow plants historically grown in the garden dating back to .Under the Heritage Lottery funding, the local authority will restore the garden as the core of a dynamic living arboretum, with a welcome and interpretation centre created along with community educational space and cafeacute facilities to complement current recreational and accommodation offering on site.Officials say the important environmental setting and bioersity of the park will be ldquoobserved and protected through educational awareness programmes, with access improved for all users.The Heritage Fundrsquos Northern Ireland director, Paul Mullan, said investing in heritage meant investing in the community it belongs to.ldquoThis is why we are proud to support this transformative project within Castlewellan Forest Park, thanks to National Lottery players, he said.ldquoThis will not only preserve the important mix of natural and built heritage, to be enjoyed by locals and visitors from further afield but will also play a signicant role in boosting the local economy in the Newry, Mourne and Down Council area.Council chairwoman, Cathy Mason, said the council had been working in partnership with a range of stakeholders, including the Lottery Heritage Fund and Forest Service on the proposal to restore the walled garden which encompasses the National Arboretum and enhance the visitor offering the forest park has to offer.ldquoThe addition of park to the councilrsquos offering will reinforce how committed we are to improving the health and wellbeing of all our citizens. In partnership with the Heritage Fund, we will deliver activities that will enhance the quality of le of our citizens by engaging in volunteering and skills opportunities, she continued.ldquoI want as many residents across the community to enjoy the green and open spaces our district has to offer, including Castlewellan Forest Park.Forest Service chief executive John Joe OrsquoBoyle, said the forest park had proven to be a very important and attractive destination for many people over the past  years.He added: ldquoThis project embraces an exciting investment opportunity and will showcase how the potential of the forest can be realised. It will also deliver against wider objectives such as health, tourism, education and sport for the enjoyment of present and future generations..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle one of friendliest destinations across the UK
story: NEWCASTLE is one of the friendliest visitor destinations in the UK mdash and thatrsquos official.Alongside Enniskillen, Ballycastle and Bushmills, Newcastle has appeared on the Booking top  most welcoming list.News that Newcastle has been nominated as one of the four friendliest towns for visitors across the UK has been welcomed by Tourism NI.The organisationrsquos chief executive, Mr John McGrillen, said the news is a much-needed boost for the tourism sector in Northern Ireland that has experienced a two year blow to an industry which was riding high after a record breaking  when revenue surpassed poundbn for the first time.He said while it has been two years of unprecedented crisis for the industry, he is pleased to know that despite the enormous challenges, four towns have dominated the top  list of friendliest visitor destinations.And McGrillen believes the tourism industry has been incredibly resilient in the face of the global pandemic.ldquoThere will be brighter opportunities in the years ahead and I have confidence that with the appropriate support, tourism in Northern Ireland will bounce back, he said.Other locations which made the top  list of friendliest towns included Frome in Somerset, Glastonbury in Somerset, Shetland and the Highlands and Kelso in the Scottish Borders.Following research from more than  million veried reviews as part of Bookingrsquos th annual Traveller Review Awards, the awards recognise more than . million travel providers around the world for their hospitality, including , in the UK.The winning list was decided by the total share of Traveller Review Award  recipients when compared to the total number of eligible properties in that town or city.McGrillen added: ldquoTourism is absolutely vital for us as it provides passengers for our public transport and supports sea and air routes.ldquoIt also generates revenue to support our culture and heritage assets and can contribute to the protection of our natural environment provides revenue for central and local government and promotes a positive image of Northern Ireland overseas, supporting foreign direct investment.Mournes councillor Willie Clarke has welcomed official recognition that Newcastle is one of the friendliest towns in the UK.ldquoThe town has so much to offer and major investment over the past number of years resulted in an increase in visitors. As we emerge from the pandemic, more people will choose to visit the resort where there are exciting plans in place to provide even more for things for people to do and see.ldquoNewcastle and many parts of the wider district boast some of the most spectacular scenery anywhere in the world and the one thing that people can be assured of when they visit is a warm Irish welcome. ldquoCllr Clarke said that over recent years, investment to overhaul the promenade and the Main Street through the heart of the resort has paid a handsome idend.ldquoWhile the resort enjoys many international visitors, Newcastle is also a top destination for day-trippers which provides the townrsquos economy with a signicant boost and helps safeguard many jobs, he said.ldquoWe have the Mournes, the sea, forest parks, golf courses and nearby Murlough which all add to the great package Newcastle has to offer.ldquoThe calibre of cafes, bars and restaurants are top notch and it is no surprise that the resort is noted for the high level of its hospitality services. These all add to the experience that the town provides.Cllr Clarke said while Covid had a major impact on the tourism industry, with spring and summer on the horizon, Newcastle will be ready to offer the warm welcome to visitors that the resort is noted for.In addition, he said the fact that Newcastle is regarded as one of the top friendliest visitor destinations is testament to the efforts of so many people, from tourism providers to local businesses and residents to a raft of statutory organisations, including Newry, Mourne and Down Council.Cllr Clarke added: ldquoIt is tremendous that the collective efforts and ard work of so many people has been rewarded with the people who come to Newcastle voting it one of the most friendliest places they have visited..prettyPhoto

title: Rare barn owls return to  nest at Finnebrogue estate
story: RARE and vulnerable barn owls have ed to nest at the Finnebrogue estate, near Downpatrick.There are believed to be fewer than  breeding pairs of barn owls in Northern Ireland, but their population has been given a much-needed boost with the discovery of a new nest site.The Finnebrogue estate is nestled along the banks of the Quoile river with an expanse of  acres of mixed farm land with half given over to the environment.In January last year, bird boxes were placed around the farm in the hope of attracting breeding barn owls over the winter.Following the use of thermal imaging in April, a pair were discovered nesting in one of the boxes.Commenting on the exciting find, Mark Sandford, Finnebrogue farm manager, said: ldquoHaving only placed nesting boxes up in , it took no time for a barn owl pair to settle. This is testament to our land management, meaning there is ample food resources available for them.He continued: ldquoBarn owl diet consists of mainly wood mice, pygmy shrews and young rats, which in turn are attracted to the estatersquos mature woodland and areas of grass scrubland which regularly throw out grain to encourage a good population of rodents.ldquoWe hope that these barn owls will keep coming back year after year and continue to add vital numbers to our small and vulnerable Northern Irish population.Mark is receiving support from Ulster Wildle through their barn owl conservation work.Katy Bell, Senior Conservation Officer, explains why this pair is so important.ldquo has been a dficult year for our already struggling barn owl population. The wet and extremely hot weather meant that most of our barn owl nest sites failed, so we were thrilled to hear this news.ldquoLuckily, this pair couldnrsquot have chosen a more sympathetic farm to set up home with wild bird cover, meadows and mature hedgerows providing plentul foraging habitat and food for barn owls to thrive.She continued: ldquoWith fewer than  breeding pairs of barn owls estimated to be left in Northern Ireland, farmers and landowners play a key role in securing their future.ldquoBy working together, we can help protect precious nest sites, monitor these beautul birds and provide help and advice on owl-friendly farming.The chicks were kindly ringed by David Galbraith, a licenced volunteer ringer from the British Trust for Ornithology .This will generate important information on the birdsrsquo survival, productivity and movement - and is non-invasive as the birds remain sleepy during the process.Barn owls are legally protected and can be sensitive to disturbance, soyou find a nest site, please leave it alone and get in touch with Ulster Wildle.Tell-tale signs to look for include distinctive whitewash pings, feathers and regurgitated pellets of bones and fur. Any information provided is strictly confidential.If you are a landowner and think your land is suitable for a man-made nesting box, or you would like advice on owl-friendly farming, contact Katy Bell at Ulster Wildle on    or email barnowls@ulsterwildle.org. You can also visit www.ulsterwildle.org barn-owls..prettyPhoto

title: Semi final awaits
story: DESPITE a nervy start and finish to this competitive quarter-final tie, Down High Medallion XV emerged as victors in what were challenging conditions to cope with in Lisburn on Saturday morning.The two sides had already met twice this season with each taking a win a piece, the most recent meeting being just before Christmas when Friends School enjoyed the bragging rights with a - victory.Down High played into the strong wind during the first half. In the opening  minutes a number of early misdemeanours from the travelling team in the tackle, at the breakdown and at scrum led to Friends dominating territory and possession as the game got up and running.Within this period the home team gathered up an eight-point lead through a well struck penalty following a Down High tackle and a quick tapped free kick on the Down five metre line after the front row had been judged to have pushed early in a scrum, which led to a try for the hosts. As the game moved into its middle stages, Down began to find their way back into the game with some eye catching counter attacks from their back three.Meanwhile half backs, George Thompson at scrum half and Ben Cassidy at out half, kicked well at key moments in spite of the wind, to capitalise on space left by Friends in their back field.Just before half time it was following one of these kicks that Down earned a penalty on the Friends ten metre line.Cassidy kicked to the corner and off the resulting line out Down mauled close to Friends line before Ryan Halpin saw an opportunity to barge over the whitewash for a well worked try.Cassidy then reduced arrears to one point with an accurate conversion.Down entered the second half confident with the strong wind now very much in their favour.Things didnrsquot always go their way with some periods when the green defence was severely tested.However, around ten minutes into the half Halpin found himself back on the scoresheet to give Down High the lead for the first time as he strode clear of the covering defence off a well-timed pass from rumbling front row forward, Mark Jackson. Cassidy added the two points to give Down a six-point margin in their favour.With ten minutes to go, Halpin played a key role Downrsquos crucial third try. Captain, Brett Kelly who had an excellent day both in attack and defence, laid the foundations for this score executing a pre-planned set piece play.Following this, George Thompson spotted an overlap on the blindside with Halpin ending up on the ball in a two versus one scenario with full back Alex Watson outside him space.The pass was timed superbly and Watson ed over in the corner for an unconverted try to take the score to -.To their credit, the home side didnrsquot accept that Downrsquos  point lead was a done deal and for the closing ten minutes, applied plenty of pressure.Indeed Friends crossed the line with one minute remaining on the clock for an unconverted try leaving a nervy finish for Down High as they sought to protect their six point lead.The restart offered some territorial respite and all in the travelling squad and those supporting them leapt high with joy when a Friends knock-on gave the referee the cue to blow the final whistle with time well past the  minute mark.Down High now face Sullivan Upper at home in the semi-finals on Saturday, February . In other games at home last week, Down High third XV bowed out of their plate competition at the quarter-final stage with a narrow - loss to Campbell College fourth XV in what was an entertaining fixture, while a select U-  team defeated Wellington College -.The other plaudits of the weekend went to the U- A team, who produced a captivating performance to defeat RBAI - on Saturday morning.The U- B and Cs, also playing RBAI, lost but put in some proud performances demonstrating the impressive depth in this squad..prettyPhoto

title: the ruc did not help in the aftermath of the mcgurks bar bomb
story: Only the TUV has stood firm on the Union and the greening of Northern Ireland   UUP rejects DUP-TUV election deal to ‘maximise unionist votes’ in Assembly electionNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionThe RUC did not help in the aftermath of the McGurk’s bar bombA letter from Sam Irvine:By LettersWednesday, th February , : amUpdated Wednesday, th February , : am  "       "  Letter to the editorMay I be allowed space in your columns to respond to a letter from Mr Kenny Donaldson of SEFF Northern Ireland was in the early phase of three decades of killings that never needed to happen,’ January , see link below.I was quickly at the scene of the McGurk’s bar explosion, in which my mother Kathleen was killed. Along with people from the area I immediately began digging at the rubble to free those trapped underneath. We were then joined by members of British army patrols who also tore at the wreckage. Mr Donaldson says that the RUC helped in the rescue. That isn’t true.    " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.At no point in the time I was there did I see even one member of the RUC ... they just weren’t there. Mr Donaldson stresses that Paddy McGurkthanked the RUC for their help in the rescue. I know Paddy was thankful afterwardsto all who helped but Paddy was buried under the rubble and when rescued would have been immediately taken to hospital. He would have been unawares as to his surroundings and also who was present. It was also pitch dark with only the lights from army and ambulance vehicles helping the rescuers. I don’t know how long I stayed there but I can honestly say that I didn’t see any RUC. To me Mr Donaldson’s letter reeks of whataboutery in a reverse psychological way. At a time when the RUC has been put in the gutterby the ombudsman’s reportI think he attempts to shine a halo of light on a completely discredited force at the expense of the McGurk’s atrocity and it’s victims. Let’s not forget that the RUC were quick to discredit the victims even before they were identied. The RUC lied when it stated that the bomb was inside the bar. The RUC victimised the victims. Mr Donaldson reveals that the RUC officer brought home pictures of the dead of our loved ones and left them in an unsecure place to be found by anyone, in this case a child, which begs the question who  shared these images and for what purpose  Again remember that the RUC was spreading lies about our loved ones at this time. Recently we have learned of security force members using the personal items from victims of Ballymurphy as spoils of war. We also know of the montages of innocent people have in the past been over to paramilitaries by the security forces. Why were pictures of my mother Kathleen and the other victims in the house of the policeman to whom Mr Donaldson refers  What  did he and his colleagues bring home  Does this still happen today  Finally I would ask Mr Donaldson that in any future reference to victims that he please study the circumstances of their deaths .Sam Irvine, Belfast BTFty years ago Northern Ireland was in the early phase of three decades of killings that never needed to happen——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: striking contrast in the approach to the football and casement stadium upgrades
story: Only the TUV has stood firm on the Union and the greening of Northern Ireland   UUP rejects DUP-TUV election deal to ‘maximise unionist votes’ in Assembly electionNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionA striking contrast in the approach to the football and Casement stadium upgradesNews Letter editorial of Wednesday February  :By EditorialWednesday, th February , : amUpdated Wednesday, th February , : am  "       "  News Letter editorialIn a Stormont exchange yesterday over the decision to halt a scheme to upgrade football stadiums in Northern Ireland, the finance minister effectively blamed the DUP. Conor Murphy said that the party had not though through the consequence of collapsing the executive.This is from a leading member of Sinn Fein, which was allowed to collapse of Stormont in  for three years until the other main partiesgranted it its price for ato devolution, an Irish language act.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.The DUP’s recent much more minor action of resigning from the executive shortly before an election is in an entirely dferent context, of major constitutional change having been imposed on Northern Ireland, compromising the principle of consent to placate nationalist Ireland.It is striking that the badly needed plan to overhaul the stadia has been stopped and the redevelopment of Casement is going ahead. Mr Murphy says it is an insult to describe the discrepancy as sectarian but it is not surprising that many football fans will interpret the dferent treatment in that way, particularly when the party defending the stadium decision is so reliably tribal and so reliably opposed to proposals that unionist politicians hold dear.It is appalling that the £ million earmarked for sub-regional stadia is not progressing.It is a huge setback for clubs such as Coleraine FC, which have waited so patiently for improvements, and which had drawn up feasible plans for them.As the IFA CEO Patrick Nelson has said see our back page, local football needs investment.Mr Nelson points out that the sub-regional funding was included in the  New Decade New Approach deal to restore Stormont.The only part of that deal that a Conservative and Unionist government intends to rush through is the part that Sinn Fein demands, relating to the gaelic language.——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: this is no time for unionist weakness on the irish sea border
story: Only the TUV has stood firm on the Union and the greening of Northern Ireland   UUP rejects DUP-TUV election deal to ‘maximise unionist votes’ in Assembly electionNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionThis is no time for unionist weakness on the Irish Sea borderIf unionist parties wish to maintain Northern Ireland’s union with Great Britain they must do three things:By Ben HabibWednesday, th February , : amUpdated Wednesday, th February , : am  "       "  Ben Habib is a former Brexit Party MEP who has helped to take a legal action against the Northern Ireland ProtocolFirst, understand the Northern Ireland Protocol is designed to break our union. It cannot be reformed it must go. Any unionists who do not believe me, need only look at the nationalist position on the protocol. They wholeheartedly support it because it promotes a united Ireland and a broken United Kingdom. Second, vocally declare their opposition to it. Indeed, all pro-unionists need to shout their opposition from the roof tops. And third, cooperate with other unionist parties to ensure unionism wins a thumping majority of seats in the May elections.    " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Abandoning those elections in protest against the protocol is not an option. Nationalists and Westminster would both sell such a move as unionism accepting it has lost popular support. They would take the opportunity to set the protocol in stone. Indeed, anything short of a thumping victory for unionism would be similarly promoted. Votes cast for nationalist parties in May will be sold as votes for the protocol. If the nationalists win there will be no ditching or even ying the protocol. It will have been confirmed. There is meant to be a vote on the protocol in Stormont in . There is only one poll that matters, the forthcoming elections. The poll for and against the protocol is already upon us. If nationalists win now, the poll in  will be academic. A victory for nationalism will result in their next pushing for a border poll. In their shoes that is exactly what I would do. I would cite victory as proof that there is now popular support for a united Ireland. There is only one policy which matters in the May elections: what is your position on the protocol  Everything  is of subsidiary importance right now. And anything less than total opposition to it would takes us closer to a border poll and a united Ireland. We are where we are because successive British governments, particularly the current administration, have turned their back on Northern Ireland. When it came to Brexit, Boris Johnson had no qualms about throwing the province under a bus to deliver his faux exit from the EU. Even now, after more than a year of damage from the Irish Sea border, Johnson refuses to acknowledge the constitutional threat posed by the Protocol. He says it is a technical problem one that could be resolved by the EU being pragmatic. His naivety is deliberate and disingenuous. He does not want to face the problem and he does not need to face it. The thing which matters most to Johnson is remaining in office and there are no votes for him in Northern Ireland. He will not be coming to our rescue. The responsibility to save our union falls to pro-unionists in Northern Ireland and their leaders.Make no mistake,unionist parties do not win big in May, we will face a border poll as soon as this year. No unionist party could surely want such a thing. Now is therefore no time for weakness or party politics. Unionist parties must set aside their dferences and work in union for our union. We need a Grand Alliance of Unionism. Doug Beattie, Sir Jeffrey Donaldson and Jim Allister carry the hopes and expectations of pro-unionists not just in Northern Island but across the British Isles.• Ben Habib is a former Brexit Party MEP——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website.
